description:
Great little restaurant for Korean food! My friend and I came here on a Thursday evening and there was no wait. The service was great and food came out quick. If you check in, you get a free order of gyoza!! 

We ordered: 
- Beef Bulgogi: this was pretty sweet but I thought it was dry. It costed about $18-$19 for a large order.
- Spicy Rice Cake: the rice cake was chewy and the sauce was so bomb. The sauce was spicy yet sweet and this order was also big. Costed about $13
- Soft Tofu Stew: THIS WAS SOOOO BOMB!! I would definitely recommend this stew!! 

Overall, the food was really good and for the price, you get a big portion. THEY ALSO OPEN LATE!! They also offer korean bbq and I'll probably come back to dry their KBBQ!
author: Quynh L.

description:
I LOVE that this place stays open late. There's been quite a few times my boyfriend & I were coming home to the Sunset from partying with friends, & would try to figure out what we wanted to eat & if any of those places were open or not. The Crew has come through for us so many times because they stay open until 2am & their food is just BOMB. We always get some type of Korean Fried Chicken because they do it so very well, & we discovered a new favorite Korean dish we both like, Tteokbokki! 

It's pretty hilarious how whenever we go out to eat at ANY ethnic restaurant & we feel like being adventurous with our order, the waitress always looks at my -white- boyfriend & says we might want to order something else because it's "spicy" or "americans usually don't like it" not knowing how absolutely SEASONED & unafraid of food my boyfriend is! Well, on this particular occasion, we got the habañero mango wings which I absolutely loved & were for once, too intense for my boyfriend! In his defense though, habañero anything is always kind of a toss-up, you gotta use it sparingly to really enjoy the flavor of your food accentuated by the slight taste of the habañero pepper. The Tteokbokki is a cylindrical rice cake cooked in this not so spicy red sauce with green onions & sesame seeds. Super good! Korean food is such a sensory cuisine where you get to enjoy something crispy then something chewy, something hot then something cold, then something sweet then something spicy! Such a balanced spectrum.

Overall, we be lovin' The Crew & everything they serve. They're polite & open late too, so win-win! :)
author: Celine L.

description:
Wanting to try something new on Noriega, we opted to walk straight into The Crew shortly after their evening opening. 

Admittedly, I've never really noticed the space before - part of me even thought it was bar. The space itself is on the smaller side, grills on one side and regular tables on the other. Like places in LA they have a steady stream of current pop music playing to keep the atmosphere lively.

My family of 4 ordered a good mix of dishes and overall, thought everything was done well.

We began our meal with some banchan staples - kimchi, fish cakes, pickled radish, 2 kinds of bean sprouts, and broccoli. Next came out the complimentary gyoza (with Yelp check in). These were delivered piping hot right out the fryer and honestly were quite delicious.

Our entrees came next. I thought the kimchi fried rice was one of the better ones I've had lately. Rice was still loose but had a good coating of sauce and kimchi mixed in. It was no frills and straight to the point omitting some more trendy toppings of spam or corn - I didn't mind, these often mask the kimchi flavor anyways.

Moving on, the galbitang was a little smaller than I imagined but the flavor was totally on point including my favorite thinly sliced japanese yams within. The broth is also an ultimate comfort food for those cold SF nights. Have it over rice. Thank me later.

Next, having read that this place is famous for its chicken, we decided to order the sweet garlic fried chicken. Pieces were crisp and had a decent sweetness to them but could have used more garlic flavor in my opinion. Some of the breast pieces were also a little dry but hopefully you go with people who are cool with double dipping....or maybe next time we'll just ask for wings.

Continuing on, the dolsot bibimbap was good but the egg was a little overdone and I wasn't sure why leafy greens was included as a topping. Cooked leafy greens are not appealing in the slightest. That said, this dish was still very good. It had just the right amount of crispy rice bits to keep the dish balanced. Probably the least remarkable dish of the night was the tofu stew. I don't think it was brought over hot enough - we had a little challenge cooking our raw egg thoroughly. It looked more soft boiled at the end of the day.

All in all, it feels good to add another locale to our food selections in Noreiga. I would certainly welcome a repeat experience!
author: Elaine Y.

description: The best kimchi fried rice in town!  Seafood pancake here is great, too.  Tonight, the owner who is also the chef, added beef to my regular order of kimchi fried rice, and Luna also treated me to a couple small bottles of yogurt drinks.  How very sweet of them.  Come support these nice folk's biz, peop!
author: J L.

description:
This is a decent Korean spot near me, and I was surprised to find that it had solid reviews as well. 
 We came for a late dinner, and the place was surprisingly quiet, although it started to fill up after a while.

The selection of banchans is just okay (2x sprouts, kimchi, broccoli, pickled radish, and fish cake). I'm not sure if it's bottomless because we didn't try ask for refills.

We ordered the bulgogi ($15) and the seafood pancake ($17), which were both quiet pricy even for Bay Area standards albeit generously portioned. The bulgogi was well marinated and super tasty, and the seafood pancake was pretty good as well, although I found the sauce a little blander than I'm used to.

I don't remember seeing tofu soup on the menu, but I'm glad to know I can easily satisfy my Korean food cravings if I ever get them!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Check in for free gyoza!

What I tried:
*Tteokbokki 
*Bibimbap 
*Gyoza 


Overall thoughts: 
*Average Korean restaurant prices & good portions 

*Bibimbap seemed like there was butter in it, a little different but delicious 

*Free gyoza was a plus

*Not too busy on a weekend but no complaints
author: Sarah W.

description:
This is my 2nd time here and we always leave happy and super full. Portions are great for sharing and the price isn't bad at all.

We ordered the budae jigae and checked in for the free gyoza.

Budae jigae: 4/5. It definitely satisfied our stomachs on a cold rainy day. I loved the addition of cheese because it made the soup creamy and complemented the spice. It comes with two bowls of rice and it's only $26! I wish it came with vermicelli like other places, but it's still delicious.

We'll definitely be back to try more dishes.
author: Valerie L.

description:
They automatically put 20% gratuity for two people. 
Which i feel is really shady. 


Edit:
This was not a split check and If you have no ability to add tip. How is it on my receipt. That doesn't make me. You run your business the way you want. But I don't like dishonesty.
author: Geezy L.

description: Don't bother, this place has mediocre food. Very basic fried chicken and very basic banchan. Being in the area, Id recommend going somewhere else to eat.
author: Debbie D.

description:
Food was good, but sanitation was a bit off-putting. I'm not sure what kind of seating or waitlisting they have, but there were empty tables and we were not able to be seated. It wasn't a big deal, so we waited at the front area with seating at the window. The server was kind enough to offer us to eat there, which we did agree to. Ain't nobody need proper seating. We hungry, so we were thankful for that.

They have a decent amount of banchan here, all made well. We ordered habanero mango wings and sautéed kimchi tofu with pork belly. The wings are a bit too saucy, which made the crispiness of the fried chicken go away faster. I did enjoy the sauce, though. As for the sautéed kimchi tofu with pork belly, both the tofu and pork belly were very soft. My kinda texture!

As for the sanitary business, we were given two cups for drinking water. The top cup had orange red colored stains in it with some liquid. That's pretty gross... I mean, a small stain, sure. This? This is a bit off-putting. We told the server and she switched out the cup on top, leaving the bottom one with us. Uhh, were these two cups in the same washing batch? Doesn't that mean that cup is dirty as well? Yeaaa... hmm...
author: Jasmine P.

description:
Came here for dinner last night as per a friend's suggestion. My neighbor, Stella, and her nephew, Chris, came along, so it was like killing 2 birds with 1 stone. We each tried each other's dishes: Stella offered me some of her leftover soup. Man, that was spicy! Now I know there's another type of ethnic food in my neighborhood besides Chinese!
After dinner, I took my neighbor and the nephew on a tour around the city, to locations I know are amazing! We had a ball!
author: Julio B.

description:
Yum! Came here late at night because I was craving Korean and this was the one of the only ones open below GGP. 

Got the soft tofu soup and it's your pretty standard "Korean restaurant that doesn't specialize in tofu soup but still has decent tofu soup". What I really liked was the fish cake banchan. Dunno why it's so good!

Boyfriend got a bibimbap and his was pretty good too.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Woohoo I'm a fan! 

The pros: 
* We we're seated even without our full party present
* Portions are good sized
* Everything was super tasty
* Chill vibe and very low key joint
* Get the deep fried oysters. They were amazing!

The cons:
* The seafood pajeon was kind of soggy. I'm still looking for a thick CRISPY pajeon... Do they even exist outside of Korea?????
* it's kind of pricy... $18 for seafood pajeon that's soggy? 
* What's with the leafy greens in the Dolsot bimbimbap? Lol that was weird and not a typical ingredient... And not a fan.
* It smells like kbbq so maybe don't go if you're gonna go out right afterwards unless you're cool with smelling like meat.
author: Mandi W.

description:
The crew is the best Korean food in San Francisco 
Highly recommended 
Gangjia tang

...
Yes, it's the most tasty Korean restaurant in San Francisco 

Environment give6 of 10 

Open hour until 2AM
But not Sunday give 9 of 10
Tasty 10 of 10
Prefect 

More tasty than all others

Service 8 of 10
author: Mr.Gong X.

description: Ordered the rice cakes and chicken wings for pick up. We arrived a little earlier than the time given but our food was already packed and ready to go & was still warm when we opened it up at home. The food tasted fine but I thought it was a little overpriced for the portion size, especially the rice cake. The size of the wings were also a bit small and not very juicy. I'll probably be back to try other menu items since I live pretty close by but I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to come here.
author: Janice L.

description:
Tasty, inexpensive Korean food that was a great find in the Sunset. In my opinion, the food here tasted much more authentic than some places I've checked out downtown, and the prices are pretty affordable/inexpensive for the most part.

The Crew appears like a late night munchies restaurant, I'm actually surprised this place isn't closer to where there's more action in the city especially since this place is open until 2 AM. We came here at 9 PM and seats were pretty easy to get. Some of the tables have grills for bbq. This is a great place to kick back with friends or go on a late night date. 

I was pretty impressed by the service here and how friendly our waiter was. There were only two people manning the restaurant the whole night and probably around 7+ tables so props to them, they handled the late night rush really well. Our waiter even noticed that our table was rocky due to a shorter table leg and secured it. I've never had that happen at any other restaurant - so much attention to detail!

The menu has typical Korean options like soft tofu stew, bbq, chicken wings, bibimbap, etc. I was told that the Kimchi Fried Rice is pretty good. We wanted something warm, soupy and filling after a long day out hiking and there were plenty of options for stews. Make sure to check in on Yelp for the free gyoza! 

Soft Tofu Stew - I opted for seafood as protein for this entree, and the broth itself was super addicting! My main gripe was that the tofu portions were pretty sparse and were floating around in smaller chunks so my expectations weren't quite met. It was still filling though, but I definitely wanted more of the tofu. It comes with a bowl of rice, but I think it'd be nice if it came with an egg as well.

My boyfriend got the Spicy Pork Stew and was very satisfied with it! The meat portions were huge and it looked really filling.

The Crew is a bit out of the way for me distance wise, but it's definitely a restaurant I'd come back to.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
One my favorite little gems in the City! 

The food is always dependably fresh and delicious. Service always prompt and courteous.

Love their Al Jigae and Kimchi fried rice.

Best of all it's open til 2am!
author: Rina E.

description:
It was ok. I don't know whats up with their gochujang..but it tasted like sweet chili sauce. 

Had the dolsot bibimbap and soondoboo. Nothing to rave about.

Small space and very quick to get you in and out!
author: Ana G.

description:
Out of all Korean restaurants I've went to in the Bay, this is the only one that serves budae jjigae from my knowledge. Seafood pancake was not only big in portions, it tasted really amazing.

I would opt out on the chicken though, the Sweet and Spicy chicken was more sweet than spicy. Not in a good way. It was sweet as caramel, which is no bueno in my standards. 99 Chicken and Bonchon are much better options for chicken. I was also annoyed with the elderly waitress who kept trying to egg us on to get the expensive options. We were going to get wings, but she suggested the "chicken pieces since portions were bigger".

We trusted her input at first, so we ordered them. She also tried to convince us to pay $2 extra for half-half, but our decision was firm on only Sweet and Spicy. And, it turned out to be a disappointment anyway. (By her explanation, I thought they were boneless but they weren't. Disgusting. Sloppy proportions. Would've gotten wings straight off the bat if we knew)

Overall, service was okay even though it could be shady as fuck. As bizarre it sounds, it's normal for Asian-owned restaurants. Food is alright, very reasonable prices considering the portions. I would come back if my friends and I are craving Korean food in SF.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Yesssss. Craving Korean food? This hidden spot it's a perfect place to go right after visiting the Golden Gate Park. I was surprised to find the number of Asian places along the street that were calling to me but we had a plan and stuck with coming to the crew. 

Arriving at about 1:30 in the afternoon we were the only ones in the dining room but that meant we got served immediately. My sister and I ordered the two dishes to split. One being the more classic spicy soft tofu and the other a dish we had never seen before - cream cheese tteobbokki. Both came with a large number of side dishes (and free refills!). 

The tofu soup was tasty and familiar. The cream cheese was surprisingly good - with a bit of sweetness to offset the creaminess of the cheese. I'd try it if you like savory sweet.

At $30 total, the meal was decently priced too! Would come again
author: Helen Z.

description: decent but nothing special .. kimchi fried rice was ok .. free gyoza was ok .. bibimbap decent and better than other two but again, nothing special. I'd go to the many other options in the sunset before coming back. Interesting that my hostess asked to check me in for the free gyoza and then there was a 5 star review. Bada-bimbimbap
author: Alex J.

description: Delicious Korean food (based on my limited knowledge). But every dish has been very good both times I've come here. The service is fast and efficient. It's a go to for Korean food, especially their soups.
author: Nilu r.
Kristie C.

description:
Having the munchies late at night? Look no further, The Crew is open until 2am every night and their kitchen stays open as well.

I enjoy coming here for a chill night with friends.  It usually isn't too crowded late at night so it's a nice place to talk over food and drinks.  The service has been great over the multiple occasions I've come.   One time the owner treated us to a bottle of soju on the house for a friend's birthday.  Super friendly staff !

The food is also amazing, you can't really go wrong with tofu soup.  I'd much rather go here than a soju bar simply because there's actually food here rather than appetizers like at the spot or tonight.  Thankfully, crew doesn't get too loud and crazy like many other places 2 in the morning.

Do your body a favor the next time you're looking for something open late at night in the Sunset.  Skip the fast food joint and come to The Crew.
author: Derek L.

description:
Craving Korean, my friend and I attempted to eat at The Crew because it was nearby and had decent ratings. We arrived and signed in along with a few other parties who waited patiently for a table. As tables began to clear and the busboy cleaned the table at a snail's pace, a party without a reset walked in and he seated them immediately. This didn't sit too well with the multiple parties waiting outside so few brought it to the attention of the staff. The staff didn't seem to care at all so several parties walked out.

Considering the dopeyness of the staff here, I will never spend a dollar at this establishment. Instead, I highly recommend Shin Toe Bul Yi, a restaurant that goes out of its way to make their customers happy.

Food: N/A

Service: 0/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 1/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Saturday. Didn't have to wait to be seated. The menu consists of Korean main dishes, appetizers, and BBQ'd meats. 

We got the sweet n spicy chicken wings, kimchi fried rice, and bulgogi. The chicken was crispy on the outside, tender on the inside, and covered with a well balanced sauce (not too sweet and not too spicy). The kimchi here is tasty and so was the kimchi fried rice. Bulgogi had a great flavor, a bit sweet and a bit savory, but some pieces were a bit too dry. Overall, the quality of food is good. 

The prices are moderate for a Korean restaurant, expect to pay $20-30/person. Service is okay and they play K-pop in the background. 

Food: 4.25/5
Value: 3.75/5
Service: 3.5/5
Overall: 4/5
author: Brian G.

description:
Good portions,  ok korean food

Seafood pancake
-huge,  crispy,  and full of seafood with every bite.  It's really hard to get a thick pancake crispy,  but they do it right over here. 

Combo
-seafood soon dubu -came complete with the waitress cracking an egg on top,  it was legit but the broth flavor was too plain, also,  there was a background smell and taste of melted plastic...maybe from a slippery soft tofu wrapper? 
-pork belly - good sized pieces and non marinated,  the waitress came and helped us cook it as well
-chicken - surprisingly juicy and my favorite of the bunch,  I typically don't eat chicken at kbbq but this was good
-kalbi - dry short ribs,  it was quite lean and dry,  perhaps a little more marinating in oil would've helped

Service was nice,  however the older waitress took our food away before we were finished when we actually wanted to box everything up

Overall the prices were directly proportional to the amount of food that you get.  This place not bad, but I'm not sure that I'd return
author: Tina A.

description:
My girls and I came in for a late dinner, we saw a clip board for a waitlist and added my name. I had my arm resting across the clip board without realizing and a waitress wearing red eye shadow, red lipstick and a ponytail pushed my arm out of the way. No "Excuse me" or anything just straight up PUSHED MY ARM. Not a good start.
We get seated and immediately notice how high the prices are, $16 for Kimchi pancake, $13 for soft tofu soup. WTF. We decide to just stay since we are seated already. The same waitress slams our water cups on the table and we all just stare at each other in disbelief.
The food was okay, but I simply will not recommend this place to any of my friends or colleagues because of the service. It was completely unnecessary and she needs to find another career because it's not working for you boo. Go to toyose.
author: Marian B.

description: The food here is ok.  The service is great for one person working the dining area.  She was taking care of 4 tables including ours.  The chicken is a little dry other wise it is good.  Maybe we should have ordered chicken wings instead.
author: Jenny S.

description: Everything tasted ok but my woke was not runny in my bin bin bob. Def ask for runny egg and your complimentary appetizers early.
author: Joey S.

description:
A nice neighborhood gem. Staff is very nice and friendly. They have a wide selection. The place is very popular so go early as parking can be difficult at times. There's a parking lot at the bank on the corner of 19th ave that you can park after the bank closes so dinners is a good time. They also offer good luncheon combos at a cheaper price. 

Their food is very tasty and fresh with large portions. The price is good compare to other places which seem to be higher and portions seem smaller at other places. 

For good authentic Korean food this is a must and you won't regret it. Their spicy garlic wings are to die for. They also have regular dry chicken wings which were also good. Their condiments are also good and you can always ask for more.
author: Andrew M.

description:
This place is pretty small, a Mom and pop restaurant. When I came around 7 PM the place had a couple of people eating. There were some tables with grills but we didn't sit there. There were only two waiters but the service was still quick. The waiters were also very polite and checked up on us often. 

They gave us six plates of banchan like any other place and it was pretty good. I ordered stone pot bibimbap, the bowl was abnormally small compared to other stone pots that I've eaten. Nevertheless there was still a lot in the pot, not too much, but not too little. The bibimbap was hot and hearty, the flavors were balanced. It wasn't greasy, it was like a homemade dish. 

Definitely recommended, gotta support small businesses
author: Donald C.

description:
Glad to have found a good Korean restaurant in this area of the Sunset!

We ordered Kimchi Fried Rice (with mild spice), Takoyaki appetizer (octopus balls), BBQ chicken, and GamJaTang (spicy pork rib soup). All dishes tasted great! They also gave us two bowls of purple rice, which was just white rice with a hint of purple from 1-2 purple grains mixed in. The banchan selection was not the best, but it was not bad either. We got broccoli, fish cakes, kimchi, two plates of bean sprouts (they tasted the same to me), and picked radish.

Service was attentive. We came here on a Wednesday night, so it was not too busy, but there was a reasonable number of tables filled (maybe about 4-5 other tables filled).

Overall, I enjoyed dinner here. Flavors were great, and the restaurant ambiance was cozy and chill. I would definitely come back again in the future if I am craving Korean food and am in the area (but I don't think I would go out of my way to come here otherwise).
author: Celena C.

description:
Came here with my wife whilst in the neighborhood, after coming across all the great reviews/pictures on Yelp. Yet, the gap between our expectation and experience is tremendous so I am compelled to offer a variant view. 

Ambiance- seats and table are sticky...

Banchan- most dishes taste bland and the pickled cucumber is borderlining spoiled.

Wings ($14)- taste like they threw some generic sweet/garlic sauce over old wings.
Rabokki ($26)- lukewarm ramen + rice cake + fish cake in a banged up, partially convoluted pan. There is nothing else.

For the price, we are deeply unsatisfied.

I hate to be the grumpy reviewer trashing small businesses, but this is going into our book as one of our worst dining experience in 2017. 

Yelp community, we respectfully disagree.
author: Michael L.

description:
I've been dying to try this spot ever since I heard such great things about it. This past weekend I was finally able to get around to visiting the restaurant and it definitely did not disappoint. 

BONUS: Free Gyoza when checking into the restaurant! 

Things to order: 

1. Takoyaki (Fried octopus and tempura balls)

2. KimChee Fried Rice ( So incredibly delicious)

3. Bibim Bap ( One of the best ones I've ever had)

4. Soft Tofu Soup (I absolutely love anything that has to do with tofu and this soup was so good that I ordered a second order. It was even more delicious with some beef and a raw egg cracked into it. )

5. Chicken wings (Garlic & plain flavor. Extremely crunchy!) 

I was really happy that there was something open past 11:00pm because that was around the time that me and my friends came to the restaurant. We were seated very quickly and were served in an extremely efficient manner. The servers always checked in to make sure we had everything we needed and although the restaurant was busy at the time, they never fell back on cleaning up our table or checking in on us. 

Service : 5+ 
Food: 5+
Prices: Very reasonable for the huge portions that are provided!
Atmosphere: 5+ 

Without a doubt I will most definitely be a frequent customer at this spot!!
author: Julia K.

description: Recently stumbled upon this place and went for dinner.  It's located in Outer Sunset which was different because I barely venture out that side.  It's small but cute inside!  The waiters were friendly and we got seated right away.  We decided to get the budae jigae and the kimchee fried rice with beef.  I've never had budae jigae before so I was excited to try it!  It's basically Korean ramen with spam, sausage, and tofu in a soup like base.  It was really delicious and very filling!  The tofu was super soft.  The fried rice was just as good.  This is a hidden gem for Korean food.  I highly recommend this place!
author: Mikayla M.

description:
Came here with the boyfriend on a Sunday night because I was craving tofu soup. If there was anything as soup being too flavorful, this is the spot. The flavor was all there in the beef kimchee tofu soup that we ordered. The flavor was bold, but not overly spicy. Make sure you order extra rice to go with the soup. 

The kimchee pancake was also a favorite of mine here. My first time eating it and I'm so glad my boyfriend introduced it to me because I want more! I usually order the seafood pancake, but I rather much prefer the kimchee one. It feeds about 3 to 4 people. Remember to eat it when it's fresh while its crispy and fluffy!
 
Free gyoza with check in! 

Excellent service!

American AND k-pop music!
author: Amy T.

description: This place is great! Probably one of the best service experiences I have received from a Korean restaurant. The waitress was working alone but she worked the tables just fine and took care of everyone. She Cooked all of our food for us!  we thought she just put the food on to get us started but she just kept coming back to take care of us! Will definitely come back!
author: Tony C.

description:
The Crew has the best Korean fried chicken wings and BBQ short ribs (kalbi). Their kalbi is so flavorful and fresh. Their fried chicken wings have the right amount of crunchy skin and chicken ratio, and it's so tasty! Their side dishes are also very tasty and fresh. I love how they include non-spicy fish cakes in their side dishes. It's not often I see Korean restaurants serve non-spicy fish cakes or fish cakes as part of their side dishes. It's one of my favorite side dishes; I can eat fish cakes all day.  
The dinner prices for each dish add up and is pretty pricey altogether, so I recommend going during lunch time or just ordering your favorite dishes if you want to save money! I believe for eight fried chicken wings it's $8.95 and $23.95 for their kalbi during their dinner hours. The non-spicy rice cakes (Tteokbokki) and fish cakes I also ordered are $10.95. (The pictures is of their food during dinner time)
The place is a bit small and tight. There's one side for Korean BBQ and the other side is for ordering cooked dishes. But if it gets busy they start to seat people on the kbbq side. The seating is a bit close to other guests to where you can hear their conversations and they can hear yours, but I didn't feel uncomfortable. 
I've ordered to go orders before and they have messed up my order, so I recommend eating in or checking your order before you leave to avoid miscommunication. 
But besides that, their fried chicken and kalbi are the best I've ever had!
author: Kristin H.

description:
CHOOSE THE CREW~

CUSTOMER SERVICE: 5/5. Shoutout to the guy who was the only server taking on 5 tables and bussing them too. Checked out checks and had to take orders on a busy night around 12:30AM. Really quick with orders and recommendations were great. Told us his honest opinion and got our water refills too~

FOOD:
SPICY RICE CAKES: 5/5. Definitely had a kick to it for spicyness but really good and big portion. Loved the rice cakes and fish cakes! Chewy and fresh and you can tell they weren't old since they were easy to bite in to.

SWEET GARLIC CHICKEN: 5/5. HOLY. SO DAMN GOOD. 100% would get it again. Garlic flavor was on point! Not too drenched in sauce and the chicken was nice and crispy. Ugh, craving them now LOL but I'm already back in OC. :(

YOGURT SOJU: 5/5. Not strong which is perfect because I'm the type of person that likes a buzz without being able to taste the alcohol flavor. Soju and Korean food just work out together.

KALBI: 5/5. Loved the charred flavor but it was pricey for only about 10 pieces. Almost $30 so not sure if I'd get this again, but the server did warn us about the price but also mentioned it was really good.

OVERALL: 5/5. Open late, great food and service. Especially the sweet garlic chicken wings!!! MUST GET. Can't wait to come back the next time I'm in SF~
author: Nikki B.

description: Delicious Korean food, great prices. Also had TVs, so I watched the NBA finals here. Service was great.
author: Wilmer T.

description:
I love the fried chicken wings here!!  They were crispy, nicely battered and seasoned while juicy and tender inside.  We got the original wings without the sauce and it was just perfect.  I would highly recommend the wings.  I wish I can make the chicken wings at home! Yummy.

We also ordered the 1/2 short ribs and 1/2 bulgogi.  The short ribs were very chewy and hard to bite off the bones while the bulgogi was soft and tender.  Both were nicely marinated and my daughter loved it.    

They gave us 6 banchan.  All of them were delicious, especially the Kim Chi and the fish cake.  The kim chi reminds me of those I've had in Korea. Very authentic and flavorful.  They were super nice to give us free refills on the banchan.

A generous portion of Gyozas (6 pcs) for free if you check in on Yelp!  Waitress also gave my young daughter yakult as dessert, which made her very happy.
author: Jannie Q.

description: If i were craving korean chicken wings or kalbi, i would definitely head back here on a weekday. As for the banchan and other items, I still think there are better options in the city.
author: Lai S.

description:
This rating is because we made a 7pm reservations and by 740pm we were still waiting so we took ourselves across the street.

8pm....we would've still been waiting. SMH
author: Craig I.

description:
Parking is easy. Food is delicious. Great service!!

My friend and I ordered the seafood pancake, short ribs, gyoza, chicken wings-garlic and sweet+spicy. Everything was sooo good! My favorite was the seafood pancake and then the short ribs! 

The service was great. The waiter was very polite and attentive! 

In other Korean restaurants, I hate it when they cook my meat because it wouldn't be as good/overcooked. But this place is great! I had the pork in the past too and it was also really good! 

If you don't want to smell like bbq, definitely come to The Crew!
author: Darlene T.

description:
K pop in the background, wooden furniture with pictures of the menu items tacked on the wall - reminds me of old school korean restaurants. 
Got kim chi jigae - lean cut of pork, tofu, kimchi, green onion and that's all. Not that I'm complaining bc if the kimchi is good, thats all you need. 
I'd say, if I had a hankering for some korean while in the area, definitely would return. Service was quick and friendly, even did the non asian thing to ask if the food was ok. 
Only thing is the side dishes - they were a bit disappointing.
author: Jenny P.

description:
Terrific Korean food. Need I say more?

My friend and I had plans to visit Tiki Haven next door but needed some food first. The bartender recommended this place so we came in and were seated right away at a small table for two.

The menu offered your standard KBBQ fare, stews, KFC, and other random appetizers (like French fries!). My friend let me do the ordering so I decided on the appetizer sampler (you can choose 3 that are priced $5.95) of French fries, gyoza, and croquettes and we decided to share the bulgogi entree.

Everything was cooked well and super tasty. Bulgogi was seasoned great, the fries were super hot and crispy, and the gyoza/croquettes were accompanied with a spicy mayo-type sauce that was out of this world good. I wish there would've been more banchan but the 6 we received all tasted fresh and delicious, especially their kimchi. 

The only negative was that service was kind of slow. It took 10-15 mins before our order was taken and even with ringing the bell at our table, I don't know if they couldn't hear it cuz I had to ring it multiple times. I hate doing that cuz it makes me feel like a jerk for doing so. 

But aside from that, food was great and service was friendly. Total was under $45, with tax & 20% tip. Great place to fuel up before getting hammered next door!!
author: Julie B.

description: I like the food and service here. The cool part.... they deliver to you while your drinking next door at tiki haven. I'll post photos on my next visit.
author: Christy V.

description: Yum! Place does not reek of cooking oil unlike other restaurants! Delicious food and attentive staff! Small place though! You're likely to wait but it. is. worth. it.
author: Michael Vincent R.

description: Came here on a Wednesday night with my family for the first time. There were only two other tables seated so there was no wait. Even though there isn't a check-in offer advertised on Yelp anymore, if you show them that you checked in, they will still honor the promotion of free gyoza. Awesome! Ban chan here isn't impressive with only six options, two of which are different kinds of bean sprouts. As an appetizer we had the fried oysters, which came out piping hot and were delicious. The spicy tofu soup (with beef) was not hot enough to fully cook the egg, and too spicy (which would be more okay if it was more flavorful). The seafood pancake was done really well with plenty of seafood. I usually don't like it when the pancake is too thick because it means it's dough-y, but this pancake was thick because they had included so much seafood and veggies, which isn't something I'm complaining about! The sweet garlic wings had a good flavor, but I almost wish the sauce was on the side so that the wings don't get soggy sitting in the sauce. The tteokbokki had the right amount of spicy and sweet with a perfect chewy texture to the rice cake. Kalbi was really good - cooked and flavored well, but at a steep price of $25 for a pretty small portion. The prices of all the other items we ordered were very reasonable though. When we received the check, it came with a probiotic yogurt drink for each person! I thought this was a nice touch because I love those, and it was a sweet way to end the meal - literally!
author: Nicole M.

description: The Crew is my favorite place to get fried chicken wings in the city! I order the the plain fried chicken wings with kimchi fried rice every single time. Their all-in-one server, bus-boy, cashier, Jun, is the best! The place is always lively at nights and they're open late!
author: Charlene F.

description:
Favorites:
Kalbi tang- the best in sf.
Intestines- soo good.
Assorted chicken with spicy sweet sauce- juicy perfectly fried chicken.
Spicy pork- the most memorable spicy pork ive ever had.
Wish they had a smaller sized dish for the intestines.

Our go to korean in the city, never disappoints (  )
author: Doby H.

description:
I've heard about The Crew from a few friends but I never had the chance to check it out until I walked by with a friend on a Sunday. 

At 7pm, the place itself wasn't very busy. Staff was attentive and friendly. With the Yelp check-in, we received a free order of fried gyoza which were pretty good. Juicy and not too oily.

We ordered the seafood pancake, the kalbi bbq short ribs, and purple rice. 

The purple rice indicated that it would be mixed with white rice, but there wasn't much purple rice in the order, say a ten or so purple grains in the whole bowl. 

The seafood pancake was good, but I was thrown off by the shrimp skins that were still attached to the larger shrimps. The batter of the pancake was also pretty heavy to eat so I overall did not enjoy it. 

The kalbi was THE BEST out of everything we ordered. Juicy, good flavor and so good with rice. Because of this, I am convinced I should be ordering more of the bbq meats instead. 

Overall, pretty okay experience. Could have been better maybe if I ordered different food.
author: Sofia R.

description: Solid place to get Korean food in the Sunset. Their Korean fried chicken was pretty good, not the best but it satisfies your craving. They put pretty big pieces of beef in the beef tofu soup. The egg we got with our tofu soup was cooked because they mixed up the chefs' snacking eggs with the raw eggs. The ddukbokgi was pretty spicy and a little undercooked (not quite chewy enough). You can get 6 pcs of gyoza for free with yelp check in (they tasted good too). Good amount of side dishes. Service was pretty slow, especially seating because there was only one person working out front.
author: Christine L.

description: Good food. Good service. We sat at the table where the meat can be cooked in front of you. The waitress told us that it is one of a few oldest Korean restaurant in the city. The small side dishes are refillable without additional charges.
author: Melanie Thu D.

description:
Best Korean BBQ in the city! This is authentic, high quality Korean food - I got to meet the owner, a Korean immigrant using recipes from her family repertoire, and was very impressed. They hit so many marks for me, I intend to be back many times. Also worth noting: their Kim Chi is famous in SF, and not to be missed! 

Supporting Women-owned businesses:  check
Supporting POC-owned businesses: check
Gluten free accommodating: check
Vegan Accommodating: check

That's a 10/10 for me. Highly recommended!
author: Melissa M.

description:
Worse than average bibimbap. What self-respecting Korean restaurant puts mixed leafy greens in their bibimbap?

Ramen looked like it came straight out of an insta-noodles packet with some added onions.

Average chicken wings.

Good kimchi.

Pleasant service.

They're open till 2 am, but that's not enough for me to return. I'd rather hit up Cocobang in the Tenderloin, they have way better food.
author: Inigo M.

description:
The Crew used to be my go to Korean place because it was one of the few places that was open late, 2 AM to be exact, but a lot has changed in the past few years. I came back twice recently to give another chance cause I'm longing for back when I used to be excited to come here. 

The quality of service has gone down and prices have gone up.

SERVICE

Every time I come here, the service has been less than stellar. The first time, I was told that the kitchen was closed and that it would be a 30 minute wait. The second time, it took about 15 minutes to take our order. The food took a long time to be ready and we had to ask the waiter many times for water, napkins, and utensils because he kept forgetting. I think they only have one waiter on staff and he is also the one making the food so it takes a very long time to get served, if at all. They should pre-set their utensils and have napkin and water dispensers to remedy this. Even having their table-side buttons to push to call for a waiter is better than waiting for them to come around 5 minutes later.

FOOD

GYOZA - These used to come free with a Yelp check in. I guess they stopped doing this mid-2016. They were pretty yummy and I liked the sauce that it comes with. It was a good appetizer to start with because their banchan wasn't filling enough during the long waits before you actually got your food.

DDEOKBOKKI JJGAE - This is very spicy. Even though the menu says it has 1 chili pepper, it has way more that that. Granted, I can't handle spicy food very well, I was with someone who liked spicy food and even he said it was too spicy. We ended up ordering rice so we could use it to tone down the spiciness.

SEAFOOD PANCAKE - I actually really liked this, it has a a good crisp crunch but the pancake itself crumbled within and had lots of seafood and veggies mixed in it. The only downside was that it was very oily. I took it to go because I couldn't finish it all the oil seeped through the box and left oil stains in my car and all over my kitchen table. So if you're gonna take it to go, be aware of that! Otherwise, it was quite good, I ended up heating it up in a toaster over at 300* and it still tasted like fresh.

I don't think I'll come back here anymore, it's just not the same.
author: Anna F.

description:
The greatest perks about this place are that it's open late everyday and that the service is great! While the food isn't the best Korean food I've ever had, it's still a solid price to quality ratio. The prices are typical for Korean spots in the Bay Area. I appreciate that they have a nice selection of meals and snacks. Given the lack of "wow factor" in the food, I think the best times to eat here are lunch (cheaper prices) and late night. The environment is more dive-y and very chill. 

I think everything I've tried can be summed up in a sentence: no "wow" factor, but definitely hits the spot. I wouldn't say that it's better than the average restaurant or another, but again - the time and service make it so enjoyable. The server didn't mind refilling my banchan three times! I noticed that over half the tables were left un-bussed for the majority of my meal. Of course my meal wasn't affected by this, but it took away from the environment a little. I guess since I came late night, the servers just want to chill out. No worries :)
author: Jacquelyn T.

description:
The birthday girl was in the mood for Korean so we spent the afternoon scouring Yelp for appropriate dinner places in the Sunset. I will say that good Korean food in SF is slim pickings...you get much better quality/value in the South Bay. However, we decided on The Crew because we were hungry, wanted good food, and had to stay sober because birthday girl was watching Hamilton right after.

Rating Breakdown:

1.5/2 Stars for Taste --
The kalbi and the bulgolgi were quite good -- juicy and flavorful as it should be. The half and half came on a bed of perfectly cooked, pearly onions that had really absorbed the meat marinade. We asked for the tteokbokki on the milder side, but the chewy rice cakes in the sweet and spicy sauce did not disappoint. The crispy seafood pancake came with whole jumbo shrimp and little oysters inside. I was a little turned off by the shell still on the shrimp and the dipping sauce was too mild. We ended up ladling the extra tteokbokki sauce on the pancake like heathens. The fried chicken wasn't bad -- fried to a crisp and smothered in sweet garlic sauce. I've had better but I have no complaints either. The mandu were HOT and crispy, but could have done with a little more filling. The panchan were pretty plain -- bean sprouts done two ways, kimchi, broccoli, picked daikon, and fish cakes.

Overall, I thought the food was good but not amazing.  

0.5/1 Stars for Value --
I know this is pretty much the going price for Korean food in SF, but it feels a bit ludicrous to pay $12 for tteokbokki and almost $20 for seafood pancake. And why pay $25 for a plate of kalbi/bulgogi when you could pay the same amount and get KBBQ buffet somewhere else. Portion sizes are moderate. Don't forget your free mandu with Yelp check-in. You can get away with paying about $20-25 per person if you don't order any alcoholic beverages here.

1/1 Stars for Customer Service --
Our server was friendly and fast. She refilled our panchan without any attitude at all (Some places give you the stankeye.) I thought it was weird that they only gave us ice water, but I'm sure they would have given us tea if we requested it.

No bonus star because, as I've said in the past, I'll probably wait to satisfy my Korean food cravings until I'm back in the South Bay.

TL;DR: One of the better Korean places in this area. Free mandu with Yelp check-in.
author: Abby W.

description:
We got 6 types of appetizer to share between 2 people, and the staff constantly follow up on re-fills. Friendly staff, efficient service. We came on a weekday night, there was no wait for tables. However, we had come here before on a weekend night, and had to wait awhile for tables, so plan accordingly. 

I like the spicy seafood tofu soup. There is good amount of seafood mix in the soup, squid, shrimp, mussel, clams. Soup is spicy and but not overpowering, I would say it is an above average tofu soup. 

We also ordered a green mussel soup, but there was a mistake on the order so it became a clam soup instead, but the staff apologized and we didn't mind. However, the soup was disappointing. They did give us a lot of clams in the soup, but the soup was blend. It tasted like a plain soup base, without much flavor. We definitely will not order this again.

We will definitely come back again when craving Korean food in the outer sunset area, but will stick with the bolder flavored food, since they seem to do a better job seasoning the more flavorful dishes.
author: Karen C.

description:
With so many Korean places this side of town, it's difficult to choose a place to settle to eat, not to mention competitive. 

My friends and I, we're definitely in the mood for some Korean, and sometimes the best places aren't the ones with a thousand reviews. So we gave this place a shot. The foods we tried were...

- Seafood Pancake
It was a big portion, and it was decent.

- Gyoza *Free with check in
Crispy and delicious. Would actually order more

- Whole Chicken with Garlic
Unspoken rule for Korean chicken wings #1
Thou shall not serve dry chicken. The sauce tasted better when I had the rest of my food for leftovers. Hmm

- Fried Chicken Wings
We order both wings, we weren't sure which one was better. However both broke the unspoken rules of Korean Chicken Wings. Ugh

So yeah, I don't think I will be coming back for a second time, especially after finding out their health inspection results... Now I just question even coming at all.
author: Arron E.

description:
Place is open late which was convenient after Santacon. The painted wall made the place look pretty. There was plenty of seating and each table was separated by a fence divider. It was pretty cold inside so we were shivering while we were eating. 

There was 5 of us so we ordered the 3 meat dish for $50 and sweet & garlic chicken wings. The sauce was really good but it would've been better if the wings were coated in the sauce instead of just on the plate. The most flavorful meat was the bulgogi. The pork belly was a bit too chewy for our liking. And the chicken was decent. The overall flavor of everything was mediocre. The banchan was normal. 

The staff was friendly and accommodating when I asked for bean sprouts like 6x! Not the best kbbq place but would come here again for late night cravings.
author: Jenna T.

description:
Amazing food and great service! My friend and I were the first to arrive here during the day right when they opened. There was only one other person inside other than us while we were there. I guess it's more of a dinner/ late night restaurant, which meant that lunch was just less hectic compared to their busier hours. 

We split the kimchi fried rice and bulgogi. The dishes were very good and filling. We wished there were bigger chunks of kimchi in the rice, but still good. It was definitely a lot of food and very inexpensive for their portions! Both dishes alone probably could have fed 3-4 people. Me and my friend were stuffed and couldn't finish the food so we had to get boxes. The food also comes with typical side dishes you would find at a Korean restaurant. 

Our server was also nice and accommodating. She checked up on us every once in a while to make sure that everything was fine or if we needed anything. Overall it was a great place and I'm looking forward to try more things from their menu in the future, especially the fried chicken and tofu soup!
author: Cheryl C.

description:
We came here for the Korean fried chicken and it was just ok, not amazing as I had wished. 

However my friends ordered some kind of kimchi seafood soup which after Googling, I am pretty sure was budae jjkigae aka army stew with kimchi, sausage, cheese, spam, and more. It was a bit spicy for me but I have been dreaming about the broth since. And for that, I increased my rating of this place from 3 stars to 4. 

Honestly, we had little choice in coming here. The other 3 Korean spots we tried (at 9:30 on a Saturday) had an hour or longer waits. This was nearby and didn't have a wait. 

The banchan was a nice touch and was overall pretty good. The chicken could have used a lot more crispness and flavor. But the broth of the seafood stood was amazing. So flavorful and it of course got stronger as the night went on. I wouldn't order the gyoza on my own but since they were free with the Yelp check in, they were alright- nothing special. 

Overall, don't come here for the chicken wings or KFC in general. The budae jjkgae was really memorable though- I would come here just for that (and ask if they could make it a tad less spicy). 

3 and a half stars but I rounded up bc that stew broth was one of the more memorable things I've eaten in San Francisco.
author: Seema U.

description: Came here for dinner around 7 and was seated immediately. I checked in and got a free gyoza plate for the table, which was great! Ordered the spicy soft tofu soup with beef. Good amount of spicy, although not too overwhelming. Satisfied my craving for Korean food. My friends and I also shared the large soju cocktail. $21! It was more pricey than anticipated.
author: Annie H.

description: Super late night Korean BBQ joint with awesome service! Definitely a place to drink your night away. Quality of the food is definitely up there, the place is small but gets the job done.
author: Alaric O.

description: The service here is terrible. There was hair in our drink. We told the waitress, and then she just left. Without saying a word, she comes back and just takes the cup with alcohol in it and then gives us a new cup. No apology and no remorse, plus wasted my drink. This place couldn't care less of how they treat their customers. If you like enjoying your time, DO NOT COME HERE. Don't waste a part of your existence by going to this place. You're welcome.
author: Juim M.

description: Pretty easy to get a table here on a weeknight so we usually just see what is the mood for the evening.  The soups and the fried chicken and beer set is nice!
author: Shelton F.

description:
I've come here multiple times with my fiance, we lived in l.a. for many years before and they didn't lack GREAT Korean food.  The only reason I'm giving them 4 stars is because the servers are always soooooooo nice.  I've come to realize that Korean food as whole is a bit expensive here in sf and I'm just not blown away by it.  The one thing I'd recommend it's their flavored soju, which we always have and its quite good.  We also had quite a few soups and they're not bad.  We got a free order of gyoza by checking in which was cool and I won't comment on them because they were freeeee.

This is definitely the spot to go to if you ve been out drinking and need food since they're open till 2 am.

Ooo I almost forgot we also had the wings once and they weren't too bad.

All in all I will keep coming back on those foggy cold and rainy nights since its so close to me, I will however be looking for a Korean spot that I'll truly enjoy.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: Living in the sunset, this place became my boyfriend and I's go-to for all those times of "What do you want for dinner?" We love that this place isn't the typical Korean restaurant. It has a lot of spunk to it, and is very casual and comfortable. Most of the time, we take advantage of the free gyoza at check-in which helps with deciding what to order. For the most part, we order the fried chicken in assorted pieces with both the sweet garlic and the sweet and spicy sauces, and this place makes Korean fried chicken oh so good. They also make solid KBBQ as well, love the bulgogi and the galbi. Those are just the highlights on the menu, and nearly everything we have tried have been solid choices. We can't wait to come back in our next visit along Noriega!
author: Monique L.

description:
First time dining here and was delighted to try a new spot. The kimchee fried rice with beef was spot on; not overly oiled or too spicy--a mistake made often with this dish. But not here--the range of flavors could all be found from the spicy tart kimchee to the mildly sweet beef to the moist egg and smoky rice. 

The wings were crispy and the sauce wasn't too sticky. Finally the Gamja Tang (pork and potato stew) was plentiful and delicious. Two servings is overkill--could feed 6! A single serving would give 4 a good taste, leaving room to try more dishes. It will be really good as leftovers with some cold rice though.

This may be more popular as a late night spot, but it was easy parking and getting seated and served was a breeze around 6:30.
author: M Lisa R.

description:
1). Tiny restaurant not really great for large parties.
2). The restaurant itself could use some updating.
3). Despite its appearance the food was pretty good.  I got some beef rice bowl, goyzas, garlic fried chicken.  (I would try a different fried chicken the garlic was meh)
4). Over all I definitely want to go back.  
5). It is easy to split meal with friends- family style.
author: Robert W.

description: This place is awesome! I love that they give you an option if you wanna cook it yourself or they can cook it in the kitchen for you! I really love there spicy tofu soup!
author: Angelynn A.

description:
Good service, and the food's pretty tasty. I wasn't blown away, but I think it's a solid choice for some Korean comfort food. We tried three dishes:

Deep fried chicken wings: just as crispy as they look, which I loved, but underseasoned. I think next time I might try the garlic flavored variety - the crunch would probably be a great vehicle for sauce.

Seafood pancake: good, but there's always room for more seafood! Texture was really nice though - soft inside, but nice and crispy on the edges.

Dolsot bibimbap: probably my favorite! Let the dish sit until the bowl stops sizzling - the rice develops a great crust that adds amazing texture. I also liked the enoki mushrooms.

The staff stayed on top of things, and refilled our banchan as needed.

All in all, I'll be back - I'd like to try some of their soups and other dishes.
author: Delia Z.

description:
Pro tip: call ahead to put your name down so you don't have to wait in line. I called at about 6pm on a Saturday and they had a table ready for us at 7pm and we got to skip the line that was forming.

We ordered the kimchi fried rice, fried chicken, seafood pancake, bulgogi, the stew with fish, gyoza (free with check-in), and soju. Everything was delicious and only $20 a person when you split among six people.
author: Alice S.

description: Nice little cozy place in the neighborhood. Come here all the time and always leave with full and happy stomach. They have both KBBQ that you can sit and grill it yourself or they can make it for you in the kitchen. The staffs are really friendly and make you feel right at home.
author: Sikharin J.

description: I got food poisoning here. When I brought it up to them they acted like it couldn't have been from them. I hadn't dined our anywhere else in the last 5 days. Very disappointed because I was looking forward to trying this place. The food was good and there wasn't any indication that the food was less than fresh. Only thing I can think of is perhaps unclean counters or hands. I won't be coming back.
author: Zardu H.

description: Ordered a bunch of food here.  Everything was delicious, hot, and fresh.  Good, interesting crowd.  Place has an authentic vibe to it compared to some of the other Korean places I've been in the city.
author: Andrew P.

description:
It has come to my attention that my initial review needs an update. Let me start by saying that since my first review, I've revisited this place several times. Color me impressed because these more recent visits have changed my mind. 

Last I was here, the waiter for our table was absolutely incredible. I feel terrible that I did not catch his name. I had a few questions about a few of the menu items and he answered them with complete honesty. I let him know that our table planned to share our food, so he suggested dishes based off of its shareability. 

For 3 people, we ordered Jap Chae (stir fried clear noodles with vegetables), garlic fried chicken wings, kimchi fried rice, and Tonkatsu. Halfway through our meal, our waiter brought us a dish of Gyoza too because he noticed I was "checking in" to the restaurant. When this place gets busy, it gets hard for the waiters to juggle since there seems to only be one waiter per shift. Therefore, if you're craving late-night Korean comfort food, perhaps plan to come on a weeknight.

Shoutout to Stella K. for reaching out to me. She shows a genuine interest in the success of this place!
author: Greg Y.

description: Small place with a good selection of seafood. A simple decor. Sometimes it can be crowded. The food is always fresh. Friendly staff. I highly recommend thus place if you wanna to eat a tasty food !!!
author: Wess S.

description:
DISCLAMER: I am not familiar with Korean food, so my review may be skewed.

My boyfriend and I decided to grab dinner after work at 9:30PM. Thankful that this place is opened so late!

To be honest, I wanted to come just for the free gyozas. Needless to say, I was impressed by everything we ordered!

Sorry for lack of pictures, but I guarantee you, everything looked and tasted delicious! We ordered the garlic chicken wings, half and half (kalbi and bulgogi), bimbambap, and gyoza. 

The banchans provided was perfect for our meal, because it acted like palate cleansers. My favorite one would have to be the yellow squash thingy. Fish cake was chewy and flavorful! Kimchi had a balanced amount of tang and refresh-ness. Bean sprouts were sesame-y (one of my favorite flavors). 

The garlic chicken wings were crunchy and very garlic-y! Not much else to say, it was simple yet delightful. The half and half was yummy too! I liked the short ribs more because it was more moist and flavorful. The bulgogi was light in flavor because they did not drench the meat in sauce. It seems as though the flavors were infused into the meat, almost as if it was smoked with the flavor. Both went well with the purple rice :) Bimbambap was delicious as well! I don't really know how it's supposed to taste, but it was sweet and juicy and just yummy. :) The free gyoza was not impressive, but it was free! 

Overall our experience was great! Our server was the only one on the floor, yet she was helpful and fast! 

Definitely will come back to try the seafood pancake! (It looked HUGE). :)
author: Harmony C.

description:
ATMOSPHERE:
The restaurant was kind of small but it can accommodate a comfortable amount of people. The noise level was average and it's a tad dimmed if you come here during my the nighttime.

FOOD & DRINK:
I got the fried chicken wings and Gyoza for appetizers and they were both great! I highly recommend getting the fried chicken wings.

On top of that, I also got Korean soju with strawberry flavoring and it was awesome! It didn't taste like it had alcohol in it so we finished it pretty fast.

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
Our waitress was very friendly and tended our table in a timely manner. She was very personable and made our visit better!

I definitely recommend going here for some tasty food and alcohol!
author: Aj C.

description:
Hungry after a night of drinking so after a quick Yelp search at 1am, we found this place. Seated right away but it was late at night so wasn't really expecting a wait anyway. Ordered the spicy tofu soup with pork, and a few friends ordered the same thing but also the chicken wings. Standard Korean sides, but I really liked the broccoli and kimchi! 

Service was pretty good as far as quickness, however our server seemed annoyed and impatient during our whole meal. I get it, we are hungry patrons that have been drinking but do not make it so obvious that you want out of there ASAP. In addition, it was super dark in the restaurant.. We had to whip out our iPhones and use the flashlight to even read the menu. What's funny is that as the night progressed, more lights were turned on... A little odd to me but oh well.

The tofu soup was okay, chicken wings were also okay, but I guess the novelty of this place is that it is open late at night so a perfect place for those drunchies.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
The food here is not bad. The dukbokki and jap chae are good. My main issue is that our group ordered the tofu soup with seafood. During our meal, there was a man who came quite close to look at our dishes. We thought that was odd but thought nothing of it. Later, we noticed the stew had beef in it! The waiter clearly knew because when we asked if it was beef and she said "I know" with no apology. She seemed to suggest we should be ok with it until my brother said "we don't eat beef." She then told us she would get us a new one. We aren't eating beef right now for personal reasons. Maybe the man who came by before wanted to check our dish. Regardless, if the staff knew it was the wrong dish, they should have immediately fixed it. 

Later, they tacked on their mandatory 20% tip. This is fine as long as restaurants disclose it up front. However, we felt they did not deserve 20% considering the issue with our order was not corrected immediately even when they knew about it. The waiter tried to justify herself by telling us she said "I know" as a reaction, not that she really knew it was beef stew. I smell BS. They did take off the mandatory tip in the end, but it was such a frustrating experience that I would not return.
author: Mansie C.

description:
No one tooold you lunch was gonna be this wayyy
clap! clap! clap! clap!
Your meal's a joooke you're broke, your food life's DOAAA
It's like you're always full at second couuurse
When it hasn't been your bouche, your app, your soup, or petit fouuurs
but!
I'll eat theeere for youuu!

Call this place "The Crew" if you want; its Korean name is "Friends".

(^_^) "Deef" Fried Sweet Spicy Whole Chicken / Yangnyeomchikin
$11.95 + $2 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-crew-san-francisco?select=en8ym0DnfC9uwclqf8H6Jw)
Dig the fried coating.

(^_^) Salt-n-Pepa-n-Spinderella Beef Intestines / Gobchanggui
$17.95 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-crew-san-francisco?select=YoECzKXO8lvPHZKl_19hNg)
Could be a liiittle bigger for the $. #thatswhatshesaid

(;_;) Chicken Feet
$00.00 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-crew-san-francisco?select=1_CsNJqcT7cZnYl7AQFIFw)
Deleted from the menu - bring it back!

#btsrslytho #saulbassesque logo honking a vuvuzela says it all.
author: Dan B.

description: Wow The Crew has a 4 star average and that's even higher than Toyose's 3.5 star average on Yelp. I live close to this restaurant and have walked by, but never tried it until tonight. I ordered the kimchi fried rice and spicy rice cakes(tteokbokki) and the food was good. I saved about half for another meal. The total was $25. It doesn't take genius to make kimchi fried rice taste okay, but it's hard to make spicy rice cakes, so I was happy to try it for the first time at this restaurant.
author: Denise C.

description:
I came to The Crew maybe one or two weeks ago with 3 other friends. I liked how this spot was open till late, had decent prices for Korean "anju" or food you eat when you drink aka bar food for those of you who don't know, and that they had a relaxed, chill vibe. 

We got the cheese kimchi pancake, chicken wings, chapchae, and makgeolli (rice wine). The cheese pancake was soooo yummy and I personally love cheese so I'm extremely biased. So yeah, that was awesome for you cheese and kimchi lovers out there. The chicken wings were alright and nothing special but still good. The chapchae was a bit on the sweeter side than most chapchae that I've had, so it was different than most chapchae dishes I've had but still pretty good. And lastly the makgeolli was pricey for the amount you get imo but I love makgeolli so I can't complain.

I loved the generous side dishes and that they refilled our side dishes when we asked without skimping! Also, the kimchi here is SO good; usually Kimchi is a very unique subjective thing but everyone in our group agreed that it was delicious.

Their service was good and they kept refilling our waters. The waiters were extremely friendly and I liked how this place is spacious enough for groups of 4+ but still has a nice, cozy feel.

I'm giving The Crew 3 stars simply because the food is good, but not awesome. This is a typical casual bar/dinner spot that is good for groups when you just want something to fill your stomachs while you drink, but there is nothing that comes to mind that makes this place go from good to great. If I could I would give them a 3.5 but alas Yelp makes me choose between whole numbers, oh cruel, cruel world. 

In my world The Crew is a solid 3.5 :)
author: Joy K.

description:
Came here because I was craving sundubu jjigae (tofu soup) and this was the closest Korean restaurant I was by, so I decided to give it a try. I got the soft tofu soup, and my boyfriend got the dok doritang which is chicken, sweet potatoes, vegetables and spicy sauce. 

I was so excited to get my tofu soup only to find out that it was super bland and tasted watered down.... I couldn't even finish it. I don't understand why it was so bland when it had 3 hot peppers on the men, so 1 star off. My boyfriends dish on the other hand was pretty good. Also, their purple rice is basically white rice. They say they mix it, but I only saw 3 pieces of purple rice.... 1 star off for that. 

They have a yelp check-in for free gyoza!

The service is not bad, the guy is pretty cool and attentive. Would I be back tho? 

Not in the near future.
author: Jamila W.

description:
Came here with a group of friends for dinner on a weekend. One of my friends recommended this as it was his go-to Korean restaurant in the Sunset district.

Wasn't really impressed with most of the dishes we ordered. 
The garlic chicken wings were tasty and flavored well.
The bibimbap was very bland.
The soup (forgot which) was OK, had a spicy kick to it.
The seafood pancake was quite soggy.
author: Alvin W.

description: Best fried chicken in SF. As they aren't frying big bags of frozen chicken pieces (which is pretty common for most KFC spots), but instead they're butchering you a fresh local chicken, battering it, and frying it to-order. That's whats up.
author: David M.

description:
MUST TRY THEIR PANCAKES!! 

I came here with 4 other girls and we ordered 5 dishes total: 1) spicy tofu soup, 2) pork belly stew, 3) Korean rice noodles, 4) seafood pancakes, and 5) spicy chicken wings. 

The pancake was GIANT and had a generous amount of seafood (octopus, shrimp, etc). It was not flimsy thin and we were all able to get 2 pieces from it. It also came with a sauce, which was pretty light and enhanced the great flavor of the dish! I was a little disappointed by the chicken wings. It kind of tasted like THEY JUST DUMPED A BUNCH OF SAUCE ON THE WINGS. Plus, the wings were pretty small, so when you are biting into it it is NOT SATISFYING (you know what I am talking about...). The two soups were pretty typical, so was the Korean rice noodle.

With tax & tip, we paid $16/person, which is reasonable but not cheap for a broke student like me. I had too much Korean food lately and this place did not stand out that much to me. But good service and seems pretty popular, considering there was a long time outside of the restaurant by the time we left.
author: Wendy F.

description:
The food I had the opportunity to try (Crazy Spicy Ramen and Tofu Soup) were average...

However the service bumps this place up to 5 stars!

I came here last night with the bf to get our Korean food fix.  We were already across the street making this the perfect place to check out. 

Tofu soup was aiiigghhhtttt nothing wrong with it, nothing amazing about it either.  

Bf got the crazy spicy ramen.  THE NAME DOESN'T LIE IT'S LITERALLY CRAZY SPICY.   He asked the waitress what she thought about the spiciness before ordering, and misunderstood her when she told him it was TOO spicy for her.  So he ordered it anyways.  I didn't realize he misunderstood her so I didn't say anything.

He finished a large beer and reordered the side dishes THREE TIMES so he could try and cool his mouth down LOL

He was literally crying half way though because the soup was so spicy, even after picking all the visible peppers out.  She felt bad and gave him some rice on the side to help dilute his burning mouth, she was SOOOOO NICE!!!!

She really felt bad and tried to accommodate us in any way she could (she could tell he was definitely suffering). 

I was tearing up too, not from spicy soup but from laughing at him the whole time.  And I did try the soup, it was definitely a soup that would make you cry from the pain if you had enough, no joke.

I deem this place 5 stars because she really went out of her way multiple times to make sure he was surviving his soup.  Thank you kind waitress! :)
author: Christina L.

description: Found a fly in their soup. My friend was so disappointed with what she discovered on our soup. We still pay for everything regardless of bad experience.
author: Caroline C.

description: I'm always a regular at this restaurant. It's so cozy and not only are the waiters friendly but the vibe of the restaurant is really homey. The food is delicious. The bibimbap and the tofu stew is absolutely delish. Be prepared to spend around at least $15 a person plus tip as price is always. Other than that enjoy the Kpop and the giants game playing in the background!
author: Earl J.

description: The worst restaurant. I ordered sweet I chickenHorrible waitress And poor service. I recommend nobody should go to this restaurant. Behaved like an educated people. The waitress was so rude and didn't so if properly.
author: Rasik W.

description: Great place for soju cocktails and food. Their chicken wings and seafood pancakes are delicious! They have a variety of choices and it's nice that they're open very late. The vibe is super chill and the service is great. It can get pretty crowded with a wait around peak dinner time but it clears out for the late dinner/late night munchies crew.
author: Evonne T.

description: Came here on a Thursday at 10 pm and it was packed! We parked 2 blocks away on the street. I love how Korean places are open late! We sat near the door and it was dark so the menu was kind of hard to see with the minimal lighting haha. I got the galbi and it was stacked with meat!! Hmmm. Some pieces were not as tender, but they were very generous with the portions. The tofu soup was delicious as well. We checked in onto yelp to get a whole plate of gyozas for free! Each person also gets a bowl of rice and the table gets appetizers to share....so it's def a lot of food!
author: Amy Z.

description: Love this place! Great hours and food! My to-go ramen place in the city. Parking is a little tricky so I'd recommend the closest spot you can find.
author: Yesenia V.

description:
Dropped in around 12:30AM on Saturday night. Only a few patrons around, seated right away and given menues. 

We poured over the selections and opted for the spicy ramen and fried gyoza. 

Ramen: piping hot, spicy, filling. 

Friend Gyoza: Slightly Cripsy Outside, flaverful, warm filling on the inside. 

Perfect spot for a late night stop!
author: Meghan L.

description:
There was so many aspect of my visit that I didn't enjoy. I didn't had big expectations either since I didn't Yelp this place to see the shining 4 stars they have here either.

Let's look inside my rollercoaster ride with many ups and downs with a weird rating system of mine.

1. Getting seated
Was seating immediately onto a table near the door (+1!)  We then mentioned to the (only) waiter that the sun was shining directly onto my face and he offered us a new table, after he cleans it up. (+1)  The waiter took back the menus while we waited  (why can't we look at the menu while he cleans up the other table??) This was probably done unconsciously though (-1) The wait for our new table was a long wait. Looked back and saw that he was taking other orders and tending other tables. 10 minutes later, we finally got our new table. (-1)
Overall rating so far : 0

2. Environment
Yay, we get a table with the bench and booth! (+1)
The new seats had a bunch of flies that kept bothering me *__* (-1)
Overall rating so far: still 0

3. Food
Free gyoza with Yelp check in! (+1)
I order the soft tofu soup which was good, but there was no spicy level like other restaurants (+0.5) 
I received my order of soft tofu before our banchan (side dishes) even arrived. Which was a sign of slow & inattentive service IMO (-1) 
There was only 4 different banchans offered, which I was indifferent about because I don't really eat side dishes in the first place. (+0)
Friend complained that her kimchi fried rice had too much kimchi, which resulted in her rice actually tasting sour (-1)

4. Service
Overall, I felt that they were either understaffed-- or the waiter wasn't as efficient as he can be. Although he was nice and did check up on us once (+1), the service was incredibly slow. (-1)

Final rating: -0.5
TLDR; Service was incredibly slow and food was either a hit or miss.
author: Jenny N.

description: Favorite place for Korean food. Always order the Tofu soup, non marinated beef and the pork Belly. I find it funny how they always remind us the beef is not marinated. As long as they have the sesame oil with salt and pepper that's all you need for that beef. Which I highly recommend!
author: Philip Michael G.

description:
To be honest, I am not a big fan of Korean food. But this place got me hooked onto their Spicy Ramen!!

Okay, lets start off how we got here. As usual we're driving around, and this time I get to pick a place to eat. I know my boyfriend loves trying new food so I told him there is a Korean place around here, and there are a lot of good reviews about this place.

We got here around opening, luckily we were not the first people who got here. The server immediately greeted us and gave us the menu. My boyfriend and I got their lunch special. I got the spicy kimchi ramen ($8), and boyfriend got the bulgolgi ($11). Also, we got free gyoza for checking-in. 

The food took while to get to our table since there was a big group next to us. But it was worth waiting. When all the food arrived, I was so excited. I dived straight to the gyoza first. The gyoza was really good. I thought it was going to be small portion but it had 6 pieces. It was perfectly done, it was not greasy or oily when I took a bite into it. It was delicious! 5 stars for FREE APPETIZER! My ramen was yummy too. It had the perfect amount of heat and spice. It was not too spicy that I had to drink water the entire meal. But it was spicy!  You can really taste the kimchi. It definitely satisfied my taste buds. My boyfriend's dish was not bad either. It slightly sweet, and it was a descent portion. 

Overall, if I am around this area again I would come back to this place. Their food is hot, and flavorful, good for a cold day.
author: Noel K.

description: Oh my god. This restaurant is so good. This is my friends and I go to place for super late nights snacks. The waiters are all lovely and attentive, and I can't express how good of a spot this is for a late night snack. I only order the tofu soup, but to be frank there are some days when I wake up just thinking how much I want that tofu soup from the crew. Is that wierd?
author: Kendrick K.

description:
Awesome environment with great service and good food.
I tried the sweet and spicy whole chicken and it was AMAZING. This chicken is worth the trip and they give you so much. I shared it with a friend and we still had leftovers. We also had the kimchi fried rice which to my surprise was a huge portion. It was really good.
We also got free gyoza for the yelp check in and it was great.
I'll definitely be back here, I love this place.
author: Bianca M.

description:
I think this may be my new favorite Korean spot in SF!

Came here for dinner on a Friday night with a group of 5 around 8:30-ish. We called 15 minutes ahead and they were able to reserve at able for us. 

The Crew very much reminds me of a Korean soju bar more than a restaurant, and they do serve soju and Korean beer. The menu is a few pages long, but covers everything anything would hope to find at a Korean place. Tofu soup, doenjanjige, fried chicken wings, kimchi fried rice, kalbi tang, and more. 

We ordered:
1. Kalbi tang - This is a hugee bowl! The soup was really light and refreshing, but still a bit creamy if that makes sense.
2. Kimchi fried rice - Meh. The kimchi tasted like it had carbonated/over-fermented and the rice itself could've used more kimchi or gochujang or something.
3. Doenjanjige - This was delicious, wish it came in a bigger bowl! 
4. Deep fried garlic chicken wings - YUM. You must order this! They're the typical fried chicken you'd expect at a Korean place, but with garlic.
5. Seafood pancake - I did not have any of this, but everyone else loved it.
6. Gyoza with check-in - Nothing much to say, just your average dumplings.
7. Tofu soup - This comes mild and there are no other spice level options. This was one of the best tofu soups I've had in the city (I don't like Manna, My Tofu House, or Muguboka). They got a bit overboard with the mushrooms, but still good.
