Service was pretty good and attentive.

Will I be back? Yes.
author: Doris K.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Friday night while visiting SF for the weekend. I'm a frequent visitor of LA's Koreatown (I've lived in West LA for the last 4.5 years) so I'd like to think I have a good sense of what good Korean food is supposed to taste like. That being said, the food here at the Crew was excellent and it definitely warrants comparison to some of most flavorful Korean food I've ever had. The side dishes were pretty standard for a Korean restaurant although there was one dish (the cole slaw I think?) that was really interesting and tasty. 
We ordered the spicy chicken wings, the garlic wings, the Korean army stew, the short ribs, and french fries. The wings were covered in sauce and super meaty, unlike those small wings that are mostly bone that are served at many other restaurants. Though crispy on the outside, the chicken was still tender and juicy on the inside. They're extremely good. The stew was hearty and packed with flavor due to the multitude of ingredients included. It was my first time trying it and I am now a fan. The short ribs were grilled perfectly, tender, and delicious. I demolished the entire order by myself. Lastly, the french fries were piping hot, crispy, and thick. What more can you really ask for in fries? 

5/5 stars

P.S. I think they're open until 2AM so this would be the perfect ending to a night spent bar-hopping or something like that.
author: Kaelan C.

description: Really nice place. I am a vegetarian and they had decent options on the menu. Would definitely recommend to try it out.
author: Kunal S.

description: Slightly below average, who puts salad in bibimbap? Apparently this place does. Dinning room was too cold, ate with my coat on. This place is ok if you're in a pinch for a late night bite. Service was decent.
author: Marcie L.

description: Stopped here on a Monday night and had kbbq. The service was amazing, best I've had in San Francisco kbbq jokes. Would def go again. Going to be my new kbbq spot
author: Michael Z.

description:
Got a crew of buddies who love Korean food? If so, come to The Crew!

Located on Noriega in the sunset district of SF is this small, charming Korean restaurant. I came here on a Saturday evening with a crew of five. It was rather quiet for a Saturday night and we were seated immediately. The service was nice as they were very patient with our multiple questions about items on the menu. They also consistently poured us tea and provided us with water which was very nice.

I wouldn't say any of the dishes in particular was outstandingly amazing, but all of them were extremely solid in presentation, flavor, and taste. The soondubu was properly salted with a spiciness level that pleased everyone at the table. The seafood pancake came in a well sized portion and went well with the sauce. The bibimbop was cooked properly in the stone pot to provide a nice crisp layer of rice along the edges. The garlic chicken wings came with a nice sticky soy garlic sauce with a noticeable but not overwhelming garlic flavor. The bonchon came with a great variety of little dishes, each of which was unique. In the end, all the dishes hit a perfect balance of flavor being neither nonexistent nor overwhelmingly strong.
author: Joshua M.

description:
I can only speak for the cook- yourself experience at this restaurant. Frankly, it's awesome. I come from the LA area, the land of AYCE Kbbq, and have been scouring the city for a restaurant with a similar experience.

Although this is not AYCE, it might actually be a better bang for your buck. Their portions are generally on the larger side, meaning that you get leftovers enough for 2- 3 quick meals. 

Special shout out to their beef intestine.
author: Pia D.

description:
Food was delicious and the service was excellent. I actually ended up there twice in one night. They also have a bbq your own option, which adds to the appeal. The spice was just how I like it for my tteokbokki and the mango soju was tasty, but not overly sweet where it makes your stomach hurt, like I've had in some restaurants. They're open late night 5 days a week and not in the Mission or Downtown also, which is also a big plus because a body can only take so much of those processed foods from 7 - 11 and next morning regret from em.

I highly recommend you try The Crew.
author: Lemuel Y.

description: I decided to go here woth my two friends after work. We ordered the Kimchi Jigae, kimchi fried rice, kimchi pancake, dolsot bibimap, and spicy pork.  My friend was eating her kimchi fried rice and there was a hair in it. I was eating the kimchi jigae and there was hair in my soup. Its didgusting because we both pulled the hairs out of our mouths and we made sure that it wasnt our hair. I honestly would not recommend coming here. Also because as i was packing my left overs to give to a homeless. We dropped our other togo box befpre using it on the floor amd instead of giving us a new one, the waitress expected us to still use the box that hit the floor. My other friend also ended up vomiting after eating which means the food is being handled improperly so it is unsanitary.
author: Mariah T.

description: Stopped by here only because they are open so late.  Was pleasantly surprised at how delicious the food was.  Yum!
author: Hellen C.

description:
They definitely deserve a 4 star for awesome customer service and for opening late until 2AM. (There is a tiki bar right next door, so this place is especially cool if you need some food to sober up)
Though the food is probably worth about 3 stars. 

When I visited with friends, we ordered 
* Two meat plates $16-$18 that comes with a bowl of rice
* Ddeokbokki (Korean Rice cake) $9
* Gyoza 6 pieces $6
 The meat plate is definitely worth getting because not only were they good and fresh, the portion is also pretty big. 

The ddeokbokki in the otherhand is meh, I've had better ones, and this one was just alright.

They also have unlimited bon chon (side dishes) which includes:
* kimchi
* bean sprout
* broccoli and carrots
* fish cake
* fermented potatoes

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description:
After 12+ check ins (#2 most checked in no less) in ~8 months.  I feel compel to update my review.  Disappointingly, I have to knock this down a few stars until something change.

Before I dive in, I want to say that the food quality, and value continues to remain exceptional, arguably superior to many others in the city.  The service is also very attentive and courteous.

My disappointment is entirely driven by this new mandatory 20% tip on weekends, REGARDLESS of party size.   This was not advertised on their menus.  We only found out when we saw the line item on the bill.  The hilarious part is, the optional tip line is still there for you to add a little something extra for good service.

I personally have never given them anything less than 18%, sometimes 20%+.  But that's because their staff is phenomenal and deserve it.

However, this mandatory tipping is pure money grab.  Tips by default are voluntary (technically by definition, but actually by our culture of passing on wages to consumers, but I digress).  I understand you may need to impose a mandatory surcharge if the party is large and there's more work, but this is a three person party.  We literally ordered three things AND we've always tipped people well.  I have two recommendations here.

1)  If you want to make more money and felt you've under priced your menu, then up the price per item.  So you and your staff gets paid more. 
2)  If this is a matter of your staff asking for more money.  Well then, fair work fair wages.  Pay them properly and don't squeeze your customers by nickle-and-diming.  

Either way, the establishment is doing their customers, new and long time fans, a huge disservice.  Frankly, its quite insulting.  What, my meager 18% tip is not enough of a subsidy to their actual hourly wage?  Maybe you need to value your staff better and pay them an actual fair wage, they work their butts off.

With that said, I am sad that I may not frequent this place as much until something changes.  At least we had a good 9 month run.
author: Sai Kiu H.

description: Came here for kimchee soup on a cold Friday night.  Luckily there wasn't too much of a wait, but this place apparently gets busy.  The biggest disappointment was the service and how slow food came out of the kitchen.  We were waiting so long for our food that my party went through a few refills of banchan.  Another issue that happened too was that our entrees came out before our appetizers.  Honestly, I think they may have forgotten about the gyoza...  The food here was alright, but it wasn't particularly memorable.  I've definitely had better elsewhere.
author: Bryson L.

description:
Some friends and I decided to have dinner in the Sunset.  Since this place was somewhat new, I decided to make reservations here.

Fried Chicken Wings w/ Garlic Sauce - could've used a few more minutes in the fryer and a lot more garlic

Deep Fried Whole Chicken - saucy but bland

Kimchi Fried Rice - huge portion, decent dish

Spicy Rice Rolls w/ Fish Cake - rice rolls had good texture but the dish was a tad too spicy for me, good, but not for me

Seafood Pancake - this was probably the best dish of the whole meal.  Huge, right amount of crispy, and stuffed with seafood

Apparently we were charged for extra services...let's keep it PG here guys... i meant the banchan.  Also, with a Yelp check-in, you get ONE can of soda. That's right, just ONE.
author: Linda N.

description: My friends actually introduced me to this restaurant one night and now I go all the time! Although the spot is a little small, wait time for a table is not actually that bad and service is quick and great! If you like Korean food, then you just HAVE to try The Crew. They have a good selection of rice plates, soups, noodles, and even drinks! I recommend the Kimchee fried rice. The atmosphere is very young and hip which attracts all the college students near by, like myself. It's very casual so if you're looking for a nice little Korean restaurant to go to after a long day at work or school, this is THE place!
author: Dana K.

description: The food here is certainly delicious. They have great service, which is a staple of any Korean restaurant and it's great they are open late, 'til 2AM. Tried the kimchi fried rice, sweet whole deep fried chicken, and soft tofu soup- all just right. This is an authentic Korean restaurant in Sunset you should try for that reason.
author: Jaime F.

description: Food was great, I had the Beef rib soup for $17.00 I was shocked when a tiny bowl came out!  But it was really really good. Just wished the portion size validated the price of the dish
author: Cory L.

description:
Went there for lunch. 4 adults, 2 kids. No lunch menu. Sat for over 15 minutes after ordering  before a few side dishes came out. Skimpy, bland, no cucumbers,  no little fish, no nori. Hey...what about the 4 and 5 star reviews?
Got the 4 meat special with soup for $75. Came with 4 small bowls of hard undercooked rice. Come on, how about 2 extra empty bowls for the kids? Also ordered seafood pancake, and bimbimbop.
The seafood pancake was good but there was almost no seafood in ours.
The chicken white meat was cut into small, thin strips and dry. Then there was about 2 strips of beef ribs with bones, I can't say how it tasted because I didn't get one of the 6 small pieces. The boneless beef bulgogi was cut into ugly varied sized chunks and was totally tasteless. The cut up spicy pork was ok. All 4 meats presented piled onto 2 small plates. Almost an hour after we sat down, the bimbimbop came out. We ordered 1 but got 2. Charged for 2. They were tasteless with no char. When the ravenous boys stopped eating, you know you're not coming back. Then the soup came. I fed the meters for 1:15, had to fill for another 1/2 hr. Such disappointment. Nephew's birthday tomorrow. Felt bad to have recommended the restauarant based on Yelp reviews. Food not only slow, but tasteless. Bill $150 before tip.
Not my idea of a good neighborhood lunch.
author: jane f.

description:
What's Good:
-Deep Fried Chicken Wings -- I didn't like the dry crust (that's my fault for not ordering their sweet and sour sauce, wonder how much better it would taste?), but the meat was dark, tender, fresh, and flavorful. I still prefer San Tung's chicken, however. [$8.95 for 8 pcs here. For their special sauce it's $16.95 which is very pricey considering Santung's notable wings are only $9-11 with 12 pcs].
-The Gal-Bi-Tang (short rib soup) -- Amazing short ribs. Delicate, juicy, and has that fatty taste that I love. The soup itself was quite rich too. My favorite dish here! Highly recommended.
-Check-in on Yelp and get a plate of 6 free fried gyoza!
-Not super crowded so the wait times are definitely shorter than other Korean places in the city.
-They close at 2AM on most days. Perfect for those late night cravings!
-Attentive servers.

The Not So Good:
-Banchan -- Meh. Not the best I've had. (But it's unlimited).
-Fried gyoza -- Very plain. I've had better gyoza through home cooking.
-Kimchi Fried Rice -- This is my go-to dish at every Korean restaurant. It arrived in a unique and aesthetically pleasing plating, with the rice in a square shaped. Unfortunately the rice was really dry and lacked the flavorful sauce. There was so much rice! I'm not complaining, but I'd rather have smaller portions and better quality. Maybe there was too much rice so the sauce didn't distribute evenly? The egg yolk was barely runny and the best part of kimchi fried rice is being able to mix the liquid yolk with the rice. Also it's $10.95, which is overpriced for the quality (compared to my favorite at Manna's, which is $7.99 with a perfected egg and rice combo).
author: Vicki L.

description:
Menu for dinner:
- sweet and spicy chicken - 8 piece wings ($8.99 + $2 to add sauce)
- kimchi fried rice ($11.99) 
-  Gyoza - 5 pieces (free with Yelp check in)

My girlfriend and I agreed the chicken was one of the best we've had in the city! Flavor is consistent, sauce is just the right amount with a glazed texture, and meat was thoroughly cooked - unlike many other places. 

Kimchi fried rice was good, generous serving, and nice texture, not too wet. 

The free gyoza was yum too, def worth the yelp check in! 

As many other Korean restaurants in the city, space is limited - there are only about 10-15 tables, and we were lucky to walk right in without a wait. Single bathroom in the back. TV casually blasting Kpop in the top corner of the room. 

Service was okay, you have to wave down the waiters to get their attention, and they always either seemed too busy scrambling around, or disappeared in the back.

With this place being in the middle of many other Asian restaurants and cafes, parking is limited several couple metered spots in front. You can try your luck finding small parking spots on the residential streets surrounding the street. 

Overall, great food, busy location, lacking service. Def worth checking out their chicken wings :)
author: Michael H.

description:
Customer service is HORRIBLE- the waitress with a black ponytail and the homemade sauce has a weird oven-aftertaste. And too expensive to be that nasty.

Although I did get a free gyoza starter but then again when I asked for sweet and sour sauce she told me the restaurant didn't do that and that's Chinese restaurants that do that
author: Hydia S.

description:
The Crew is a cozy little Korean restaurant in the Sunset district.  My sister and I had just finished working out at the gym, and we were looking for some food to eat at 11pm.  This place is open late til 2am!!  My sister had been here once before, but it was my first time.

We got in and were seated immediately.  There were a couple of other parties of guests eating, drinking, and chatting it up.  The TV was playing Korean MVs, which could be entertaining to watch when you're waiting for your food.  We decided on the bulgogi, soft tofu soup, and gyoza, which was free with a yelp check-in!

SERVICE:
Our server was very attentive and friendly.  Right off the bat, I felt welcome.  He gave us time to decide but also checked in when were ready.  He noticed that I had the yelp check-in offer ready and basically affirmed that he got me on the gyoza.  When the food came, he was kind to remind me to crack the egg into the tofu soup to cook.  Also, as I was getting rid of any potential wood splints, I dropped one of the chopsticks on the floor.  He was quick to bring me a new pair of chopsticks!  Service was great, at least at that time and day.

FOOD:
There were 6 different banchans - ranging from fish cakes to seaweed to kimchi.  I always enjoy the fish cakes.  The yellow radish was good, but it tasted/smelled like fish (??).  Anyway, the kimchi was surprisingly good.  I am a bit picky about kimchi, but I liked this one!  Okay, now let me tell you about those free gyozas - they are sooooo good!!  I don't know what it was, but they tasted delicious.  They came with the sauce and were perfectly crisp.  The soft tofu soup we ordered was only available in mild spicy level, whereas at other Korean restaurants, you can choose from no spice to extra spicy.  But I thought it was fine because I didn't want it too spicy anyhow.  You do get your choice of meat (beef, seafood, pork, vegetable).  Our server gave us bowls and a ladle so we could share the tofu soup amongst each other, which was really nice.  The bulgogi was good, nothing too special but hits the spot with the flavors.

COST:
With bulgogi at $17.95 and soft tofu soup at $11.95, our meal came out to around the $30 range.  It's a bit pricier than average, but it was good!  Also, it's not easy to find good food late at night.  I would probably only come here late at night because there are other places with lunch special prices.

Overall, we liked this place and it tips on the positive side due to the great service!
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
I'm always wary about trying new restaurants unless it's from a known chef, it's a spin off or a sister of a popular restaurant. 

Seeing "The Crew" pop up under the hot new business listing on Yelp six months ago, I couldn't help but think that the sons of a some mama-san decided they wanted to leave behind their life of sex, drugs, and booze to play house so they opened "The Crew". What can I say, my dubious mind wanders all over the place and that's the first thing that came to me when I saw the name.  

It wasn't until I recently saw Victor G.'s recent of The Crew that I wanted to give it a try. This man has nearly 7k reviews after all so he definitely has some Yelp cred with me.

While The Crew advertises to be Korean and Japanese fusion, it's more Korean-centric as there were only takoyaki, gyoza, karaage, and grilled saba for the Japanese items on the menu. We came during lunch and they offered lunch specials including a bulgogi burger which I would love to try next time.

They don't use MSG and are very light on the seasoning so the food is a bit bland but that's fine with me since a dab of gochujang (fermented chili paste) does wonders for most Korean dishes. It's not the best Korean food in SF but it's decent and they have some definite stand-outs. Besides it's a big step up from the former craptastic Korean restaurant, Pine that The Crew took over: http://www.yelp.com/biz/pine-restaurant-san-francisco-3. 

We started with the obligatory banchans which were ok: http://bit.ly/HxXc8y. Some lacked heat and tang but the eomuk (fishcakes) were solid. Then, came the Gyoza ($5.95 value) which was FREE if you check-in on Yelp: http://bit.ly/174VeCH. These were nicely crunchy with a fresh pork and cabbage filling. They didn't taste like they came from aisle 6 of Kukje Supermarket (frozen dumplings are normally packed with sodium) so they may be made in-house or bought from a local distributor? 

Aunt Flo came a knocking over the weekend (sorry TMI) so I was in need of Korean comfort food. Needless to say, a sizzling pot of Dolsot Bibimap ($12.99): was in order for me: http://bit.ly/17Dh3z5. After letting it settle for a while to form that crunchy rice crust, I mixed up all the fresh veggies, beef, and rice, drizzled some gochujang and went to town on that bad boy. It was a bland but again, the gochujang solved that problem. My only gripe is I wish they used more sesame oil and heated the dolsot longer so more of a caramelized crust could be formed: http://bit.ly/Hu4Z71.

Being a kalbi slut, Mr. NSS went with their Kalbi Lunch Special ($12.99): http://bit.ly/174XJFa. He tried to be nice and give me a piece but I know how much he loves his kalbi so I just took a bite. It was tender with a nice char and a subtle savory sweetness. He loved it and devoured each piece like it was his last. Bare hands and all. This guy won't even eat egg rolls without wrapping it first with protection (no pun intended).  

The highlight of our meal was the Korean Fried Chicken (KFC). You can get a whole chicken for a very reasonable $14.95 but there was no way we can finish that along with our main so we ordered the Fried Chicken Wings (6 pieces - $8.95): http://bit.ly/1gpetiG. I'm not a fan of Western fried chicken (too heavy and greasy) but The Crew reminded me just how much I love KFC; the Korean kind. Piping hot, the wings were encrusted with a light and deliciously crunchy batter with a succulently juicy center (not greasy). It was also lightly seasoned so you can taste all the natural chicken goodness.  This KFC was definitely way better than nearby Shin Toe Bul Yi's KFC which is so overbattered and overrated (I must have been smoking something to give them 4 stars). 

We were the only ones there during lunch time so service was very attentive. While I appreciate attentiveness, our sweet waitress was very eager to please and must of passed by at least 10 times during the hour we were there. It was awkward trying to shovel food into your mouth with one hand and holding a wing in another without looking like a sloppy heffer. Oh well, at least she didn't judge us. As we were leaving, our sweet waitress and the chef/owner thanked us which was a really nice gesture as you rarely see this at Asian restaurants. 

I forgot to mention, The Crew is also opened till 2 am EVERYDAY so you can get sloshed next door at Tiki Haven then faceplant into a steaming bowl of soondubu or a sizzling bowl of bibimbap. WOOT! Sounds like my kinda weeknight. Too bad this grandma KO's while watching Golden Girls (gotta love the slutty Blanche) before it's even time to leave the house. *Le sigh*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Yay to a good Korean place with no wait that opens until 2am!!

Tofu soup and seafood pancake are both good! Received free order of gyoza with yelp check-in. Overall, pleasantly surprised, had a good experience and would definitely come back!
author: Iris H.

description:
Love this place. The kimchi is the best compared to any other Korean restaurants in the city. Their pork and potato stew is to die for and my current favorite. Don't forget to order the galbi or you're missing out! 

This place also does grilling (kbbq) and I come here at least once a week since its in the neighborhood. They're open late (until 2am) at night, so I would definitely come here for a bite when you're drunk and hungry or just craving Korean food!
author: Grace T.

description:
Really great Korean place in the Sunset district!

There was only one waitress when I went, and she was very sweet and attentive.

My friend and I ordered 1 small mango soju cocktail, gamjatang (spicy pork + potato stew), sweet&spicy wings, and gyoza (FREE W/ yelp Check-in!)

The mango soju had an interesting tangy taste to it, one that I wasn't familiar with having ordered mango soju in the past, and was a bit too sweet for our liking, but incredibly strong. The gamjatang was probably one of the best I'd had in the bay area, really hearty and good. We ordered a 1 serving of that and split it and it was more than enough food. The wings were seasoned really well, but a bit on the small side.

Overall, the food + drink were really yummy and the service was great. They have a pretty extensive korean menu, and even have two bigger tables to bbq/cook meat. Will definitely have to try that the next time I go in! :)
author: Lauren C.

description: The only place in SF that has good  (pork belly). If you want good bbq that you can grill by yourself, this is the place to go. They have good  (giblets) as well. Yeah it's not all you can eat but if you don't look at price whenever you go out to eat, come to The Crew! It's not that expensive so chill out about the price. I mean it is KOREAN food! I don't know why people are complaining about the ambience of this restaurant but it's a Korean restaurant! You shouldn't expect a fine dine environment and 5 star service but they DO give AMAZING service and their food is actually pretty good! I usually go here when I fiend Korean bbq. Their kimchee jji gae hits the spot! Don't look at all the reviews, just try it out for yourself and you be the judge but if you don't eat here, you are missing out!  Parking is okay depending on what time you go, I usually head there after work which is around 11pm and it's usually good around that time. They accept cash and cards so you don't have to worry about how you're going to pay (:
author: Isaac K.

description:
I was craving some korean food and wanted to try a new place.  This place looked promising.

dolsot bibimbap = average
spicy seafood tofu soup = average
garlic wings = below average
service = average
price = above average

Well that $60 that wasn't very well spent.  Thanks Yelp!
author: Yeeman N.

description:
Been wanting to try this place and finally got a chance to with a friend the other week. I'm glad I tried it because it's pretty darn good. 

We got seated right away and got water and menus quick. We sort of knew what we wanted already so it was easy to order. We opted for the kimchee fried rice, spicy tofu seafood soup, wings with sauce and got the free Gyoza with check in on Yelp. Everything was really tasty and we loved the tofu soup. The kimchee fried rice was really good but a huge portion so we ended up taking more than 75% home. The wings were okay. Their ban chan selection was also good. Oh! And the Gyoza was also good, not only because it was free but it was nice and crispy and flavorful.

I would definitely go back when I'm craving that Korean drinking food!
author: Tiff C.

description:
Some CREW-cial flavors of Japanese Korean fusion food here! Came here late Monday night when I was on the brink of flipping a table from studying for my finals. It was quite empty at 11:00pm but I mean who else besides my fata$$ would want to consume a mountain at such guilty hours. The environment was pretty chill and it's gives you a comforting feel like you're just chilling with yo CREW at home kinda ambiance. 

Takoyaki  $5.95: 4 stars. Comes in 6 pieces of heavenly fried ball shaped octopus and tempura scraps. It is a wheat flour based batter. To be quite honest, this is my first time having takoyaki (I know.. where have I been all my life right?), so I cant really judge if its super good or how it's supposed to be like this or that, but its entirety melted in my mouth like butter and it tasted pretty good to me. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-crew-san-francisco?select=lruBNQRQsnA0aisXoIY6pw#JA7Y7UgFKWb53TCzpV_j3g

Japchae $11.95:  4 stars. Amazingly prepared yam noodles and vegetables sautéed in sweet house special sauce. I am a big fan of Japchae, yet I am lazy to learn how to cook it even if  I heard it was pretty easy to make. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-crew-san-francisco?select=lruBNQRQsnA0aisXoIY6pw#lruBNQRQsnA0aisXoIY6pw

Korean Sweet and Spicy Whole Chicken $16.95: 4 stars. A whole chicken fried in some special sweet and sour sauce. It was not that spicy (which I am super thrilled about because I am a big wuss and cant even handle hot cheetos). The batter was not thick but it was creamy-ish in a way. It reminded me of San Tung chicken but the Korean version. Some parts of the chicken was hard to eat because of all the bones and weirdly shaped pieces, but other than that it was pretty good! BIG PORTIONS! 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-crew-san-francisco?select=lruBNQRQsnA0aisXoIY6pw#YOTbgNgeowDBCJ88CTff8w

Very friendly staff, good music, and easy parking (free after 6pm!)
author: Chena N.

description:
Please do not let the Health Inspection report stop you from eating at this great small restaurant.  Two yrs in the row, its reports were great, last year for some reason, it got bad report, however, all have been corrected immediately, and the owner showed me all of the approved corrections by the Health Dept., and all of them were dated as of March 2015 as well.  So, the Health Score should've been updated accordingly and in a timely matter, but unfortunately it hasn't happened until today yet, it's been almost a year.

My husband and I are regular customers, and we even went to this restaurant after the inspection, and we were always fine.  And the last time I was there, was today.  The foods are always tasty and great, the service is always good.  So, having this bad score (and of course having Yelp lists the score and warning just makes it worse), is really hurting the business.  

The owner has tried numerous times to contact the Health Dept. to update the score, but no luck.  I really pray The Crew will have another inspection very very soon, and it will receive a great score, which will restore its reputation and gain more customers.  In the meantime, please come to this authentic Korean restaurant, enjoy the yummy foods and service.
author: Meiko S.

description:
My friends recommended this place for local Korean.....thanks a bunch....

This small place beats quite a few places in Oakland....

We ordered kalbi....tofu soup...n seafood pancake....all was very good

The best was the banchan. ....so good....and when they refilled...they filled it up

The flavors were there....meat wasn't dried up....just very good
author: Leslie Y.

description: Very friendly, food is awesomely prepared and good service. The bonchon is yummy. Free gyoza via yelp app and i like their free yogurt drink
author: Faustino R.

description: This place has a really good kimchi pancake, wings, and spicy sausage stew. There's a decent selection of flavored sojus (strawberry, lychee, and yogurt were all solid) and The Crew's staff is very accommodating. Jun was our server and was incredibly gracious about playing our music requests while also juggling 7-8 other tables and bringing out my birthday cake. 5 stars for the service alone :) will definitely be back since my bf has a mancrush on Jun
author: Skye L.

description: This place was excellent. Quick service and even better food. The menu pictures are on the wall for you to look at to get an idea of what you are getting. The SPICY PORK is just as advertised in the menu. You better ask for milk if you cannot handle it. This lunch special packs a punch and meets expectations in all areas. Just an overall pleasant lunch and great meal. I will be back again after the incredible service and meal. There is so much to choose from that you have to come back. Highly recommend to anyone with a KOREAN FOOD appetite.
author: Robert F.

description: I got the crazy spicy ramen and there wasn't anything special about it. More like spicy ramen that you make from instant noodles.
author: Becky H.

description: Good food, a little pricey for late night munchies but usual price if you're looking for Korean food. Friendly staff!
author: Janna E.

description: Not the best Korean I've ever had, but a decent option in the Sunset. They honored the free gyoza with check-in which was awesome. Service is fine, again nothing stellar but okay. Friend and I split the seafood pancake, soft tofu soup, and kimchi fried rice. The theme of the meal was..."ok, this is decent." My friend really liked the spiciness level of the kimchi fried rice. Overall, if you're craving Korean food and are in the area, it's a reasonable option. If you're wanting amazing Korean food, I'd go elsewhere.
author: Diane G.

description:
I grew up eating amazing LA Korean food so it's hard to find food that compares in SF. Still, I think this place is pretty good. Way better than Manna. 

Food: I've only tried 3 things here - 
Dolsot bibimbap: Great! This is always my go to. Getting this dish with the hot stone really does make all the difference. In my opinion, I wouldn't get a bibimbap unless I could get it in a hot stone pot. Make sure to let the rice harden on the sides so that you can get a little crunchiness. 

Kalbitang - Great! I had this 3 times when I was sick. It's a very large dish but I ate it all. The soup is very tasty, probably filled with a lot of sodium...which it should be! The kalbi is also good and they give you a good amount of meat. You've probably never had this unless your Korean, but it's a great sick or rainy day dish. 

Kalbi - Yum. I think it's a tinnnny bit over marinated, but I'd rather that than have it be bland. I'd definitely recommend getting it and it's always a crowd pleaser. 

Banchan - They gave us 4-5 different options which was great. If you order to-go, they make sure to give you a container for them as well. 

Service - Every time I go, I have great service! Our waiter was super friendly and very accommodating, especially considering he was the only waiter working. 

Space - The restaurant itself isn't anything fancy, but it's nice enough in my opinion. 

The one thing I'd like to see is more of is variety on the menu. I think it's hard because they're catering to a lot of non-Korean eaters though. Next time I go, I want to try the soondubu!
author: Elizabeth K.

description: The service was very poor. The server girl just ignored us while we were eating dinner there. Even worse, the foods are not authentic Korean and yet expensive. Avoid this restaurant!
author: Sam C.

description:
Service = Excellent.  There's only one server working, and she is super friendly and manages to always check up on us.

Price = Lunch special price was decent. We got something off the dinner menu and that was a lttle pricey, but just about the same as other Korean restaurants. Cash or credit.

Setting = A little beat down, but still clean.

Food = Decent, nothing shockingly delicious. We got short ribs and seafood tofu soup.

Parking = Meter. Could be hard to find during rush hours. We found one pretty quickly at around 12:00PM on a Friday.
author: Vivi S.

description:
Finding a place to eat, so late in the night has always been quite a challenge -even on a Friday night. Especially a place that will accept your food orders when most food places have their "last call" and last kitchen orders already placed.

It was a quiet night out after the movies with close friends and our significant others when my friend, Violet, suggested this place to eat. She's a huge foodie, so I was pretty excited to try a place she suggested but this place, was much more than I expected. Although this restaurant is not as big as other Korean places I've been to, this place is definitely in my Top 5. 

The soju, is quite strong. That's nice, since the soju I usually get at Tonight or Mokutanya tastes more like juice and since I was trying to get a nice buzz, this place really tickled my fancy. Plus there are more flavors to chose from. The downfall is that they don't have the cool effects that tonight has: the soju in the fruit bowl or the dry ice effect that releases from under the hollowed out fruit.

The food portions here are really good, significantly bigger than Tonight and the selection has a nicer variety of food. There was definitely something for everyone here and the portions are so big, everyone took a box home or was completely stuffed. The spices hit at the right spot, so there's no feeling of heartburn nor was anything hard to swallow.

Back to the size of this place. It's not as big as most food places I've been to, but somehow, this places manages to make one feel homey so it doesn't feel cramped -at all. People are talking to one another, laughing and being drunk without annoying other customers or jumping into other people's conversations.

Overall, this place is really good. I'm definitely planning to return.
author: Shilo B.

description:
My favorite type of food is Korean. That said, this place is not bad! The price is not cheap, but not as expensive as AYCE BBQ. The food is good, but the portions are not as big as my expectations compared to how much I paid for the food. They should hire more people to work, as two servers per night, they are always swamped with customers. The place is cute, but my main concern always as a consumer is the food, unless the service is that horrible.

Good service for the amount of servers they have. Food is yummy. Tofu soup sometimes has too much MSG but sometimes also none that I could notice. Order the chicken and tofu soups. There is also usually a wait, so come thinking you'll need to wait! The wait is worth it for the quality of Korean food around this area!
author: Natalie T.

description:
In comparison to the many Korean hot spots in the sunset, I'd be much more willing to give my business to this place, and here are the reasons why:

1. Parking was incredibly easy to find.
2. The service was super friendly! Our waitress was nothing but smiles and was super sweet.
3. Their portions, esp for the kimchi fried rice, were huge.
4. Their garlic fried chicken was soooo good.

I'd have to come again and try their soju to see if I'd make this my go-to spot. And they're open late, which means I can come here and drink w my friends. Winnnnningggg for sure.
author: Audrey G.

description:
In college, there was a little Asian noodle station that changed up the type of noodles daily. One was apparently Korean japchae, and I loved it! They put thinly sliced zucchini in it and the sauce was wonderful. It was one of my favorite days! 

I figure, I'm in the area, take advantage of the Korean available. I yelped Korean in Inner/outer sunset area, near UCSF, and found this was the only one open in the middle of the day. It looks newer too, so that is a plus, to me, it means it will probably be cleaner. 

I head over, and the server guy was super friendly and approachable, and didn't make me feel like a P.I.T.A. by ordering to-go. $10 minimum for credit card. I ordered the entrée portion of the japchae, I wasn't interested in the lunch special for a couple bucks less (from what I saw online) and some Korean spicy ramen (Hey, I was trying to kill two birds with one stone since I seem to be a ramen addict). It was total around $22 dollars I think. 

I know the quality was probably compromised by being to-go, but the ramen was inedible. By the time I got to my hotel room, the instant ramen noodles were mushy and had soaked up the entire bit of broth. I couldn't eat that after having real ramen. 

The japchae was just okay. It was not as good as what I could get in college and no zucchini whatsoever, even though descriptions says vegetables. A lot of onions. I took out most of them and just ate the noodles and slivered carrots. I'm not for sure, but if I got an entrée portion, it was pretty small in my opinion. It did come with the Korean sides (Banchan?), broccoli, something yellow, cucumbers and the spicy cabbage stuff. I loved the yellow pickled things and the broccoli, the cucumbers were a little lackluster for me personally, but I like Japanese style cucumber salad which is pretty strong. I'm not sure if the sides always come or not, I feel like they still gave me a lunch portion.  

Overall, even though the service was great, the food didn't impress me and I won't be back, even if I lived in the neighborhood.
author: Tabitha E.

description: Geez, the food is amazing here. We used the check in offer for an order of gyoza and it was great. There are 6 free sides that are out in the table and they were all really fresh and delicious. We ordered two entrees; the spicy pork and the short ribs and both were outstanding.  We will definitely be coming back here.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Apparently, crazy spicy Korean spicy ramen equals self imposed challenge to my boyfriend.  
The ramen came with deep red broth and the spicy aroma from the floating dried red peppers. It doesn't look so bad...until you sip the third spoonful and started to feel as if your tastebuds were on fire. 
We started to sweat, gulping cold beers like crazy, sipping the hot painful broth as fast as we could, blowing with our swollen lips, and wiping our tears with our sleeves. The heat subdued 5 minutes afterwards so I don't think it was made with ghost pepper or carolina reaper stuff. and honestly it wasn't unbearable. It's like fire noodle with broth version, just the hot broth makes it more painful to ingest.
It was a fun experience for spicy lover and perhaps to surprise your unsuspecting friend.
Kalbitang was delicious with juicy tender short ribs and well cooked radish. Service was a bit slow (due to shortage of hands?) but the servers are nice.

On the fun note, even after complaining how it feels like Satan rapes his *bleep* when he did his 'business'; boyfriend still murmured he will ask for triple spicy next time. Man. :)
author: Jenny T.

description: The food was good (I always enjoy tofu soup) and it's a great deal, but the compromise is that the ambiance/space isn't great. The restaurant was cold inside (even with my jacket on).  I ordered hot tea to warm up, but I didn't get it until my dinner appeared and I reminded our waitress.  Our table was by the door, and there were people waiting for tables, and since there is no waiting area, people stood around/by our table throughout our meal.  I'm surprised people were waiting inside, since it wasn't any warmer inside than outside. Perhaps on a less busy night, it would be a more pleasant experience.
author: Denise A.

description:
Came here on a weekday for dinner around 7:45pm and it was pretty busy. Didn't need reservations or anything but we got the last table available. Overall food was decent but service was very slow.  We had to flag our waiter down quite a few times throughout the night. But he was very nice and accommodating so we weren't mad/pissed off. Definitely a good place to catch up with friends over drinks and food. And they stay open til 2am! 

We ordered: 
Seafood pancake - not skimpy on the ingredients but way too mushy. Need to request for extra crispy next time. 

Fried chicken wings - Mixture of wings and drumlettes. they offer a few different type of sauces. We went with the garlic honey? sauce and it was pretty good. Sweet n savory. Chicken wings were moist and very crispy. 

Gyoza - Free with yelp check in. Decent. Deep fried pork dumplings. Not complaining cuz it's free. 

Kalbi Tang - short rib soup.  pretty good. Broth was light but flavorful. In addition to the daikons it also had clear vermicelli noodles in it. Not skimpy with the meat n veggies but I wished there were more broth. 

Pork Belly - My fav meat dish. Nice n fatty n juicy. Goes so well with the dipping sauce they give u. I think it's some kind of sesame oil mixed with black pepper. 

Spicy Pork - I don't care for this dish but my friends always order it. It was decent. At least the meat wasn't all dry and old tasting. 

Banchans were very limited. I believe only 5-6 diff kinds. Enjoyed the marinated cucumbers but couldn't get any refills cuz they ran out. Yup that was disappointing. I LOVE banchans, especially the "refill" part of it. 

My fav K place in the area would still be Toyose (best kimchee fried rice) but The Crew would be a good alternative with less wait time and more variety of food.
author: Cathy M.

description:
The Crew is a new Korean-Japanese fusion spot that recently opened in the Outer Sunset.  The space is quite small, but fortunately it wasn't busy when we came on a Thursday evening.  The Crew serves  BBQ, soup, stews, jap chae, and bibimbap to name a few of the items.  

We ordered:

*Takoyaki ($5.95 / 6 pieces) - Not bad.  It was fried perfectly and not drenched with   sauce.  I liked that there was a good amount of tako and that I wasn't just eating fried batter.

*Fried Chicken Wings ($8.95) - This came with a side of cole slaw and it reminded me of KFC's hot wings, but it wasn't spicy.  I wished they marinated the wings or seasoned it with salt & pepper as it was flavorless.   I actually ordered the wrong item as I initially thought this would be similar to San Tung's dried fried chicken wings.   I wouldn't recommend ordering this dish.

*Kimchee Fried Rice ($10.95) - The menu doesn't  state that there is beef in the kimchee fried rice.  So if you're a non-beef eater, make sure you tell them to omit the beef and substitute it with chicken, pork, or just have it meatless.  I don't eat beef so when I ate a spoonful, I was thrown off.  I wish I knew The Crew makes their kimchee fried rice with beef because I wouldn't have ordered it or would have asked them to omit it.  The dish itself was okay.

*Pork Belly ($16.95) - The dish came out on the typical iron plate and was pretty flavorless. For the price, I'd probably choose one of the other meat plates.

Overall, I'd give this place another shot.
author: Candice H.

description: This place is amazing always knows how to take care of their customers. I always order the Kalbi because it tastes delicious. The owners rocks and the daughters heheh
author: Winston L.

description:
The great thing about this place is that they are open till 2am and if you are drinking around the bars near by and don't want to or can drive anywhere this would be your best shot for a meal. 

The food on the other hand is not great considering how much they charge per dish if it was higher quality food I wouldn't mind paying for it. 

The restaurant has a cute setup and the service is good.
author: Yas J.

description: Service was great. Food was so-so. Ordered bulgogi for me and I dislike veggies. "Too many onions," and not enough beef.  My mom ate some of the potstickers that were free because she checked-in Yelp. ( written by a nine year old)
author: Marsha Q.

description: This is my go to Korean Place since it is near my house and easy to find parking. The Seafood Pancake, Tofu Soup, Kimchi Fried Rice & BBQ Combo is my favorite. Service is always on point.
author: Irene D.

description:
I came on a Thursday night. It was relatively full. Service is good. However, food comes out pretty slow. There is a lot of waiting between dishes. Also, it's a tad bit dark because of poor lighting. 
Parking can sometimes be hard, so carpool if possible. 

My cousin and I ordered the sampler appetizer: fried calamari, Chicken Karage and Takoyaki  (17), kimchi fried rice (11) and seafood pancake (14). 

First up, was tea which came out fairly quickly. Next was the complementary bowl of edamame beans. The two of us received exactly 7 string beans. It was baffling. Maybe it was because the bowls were too big? It was poor presentation. 

Fried Calamari comes in ring shapes and they do not skimp on the calamari-batter ratio! This was delicious! I would definitely order this again. 

10 minutes after we finished our calamari our kimchim fried rice came. When ordering, I asked for my egg to be cooked all the way through. They caught their mistake before our order was brought out. How do I know?  I had the perfect view of the kitchen. I watched the cook pluck the egg off with their fingers and slide it back onto the cooking station. They put it back on top with a silver oval cooking spoon. The rice is not overly spicy and people who cannot tolerate spicy food, should be able to tolerate the light kick. I'm not sure if it is because kimchi fried rice was on such high demand that night, but our rice had a too "fresh" texture which made it a bit on the mushier side. 

I realized I was getting full. We were still waiting on 3 dishes! Our chicken karage and takoyaki came about 5 minutes after asking. The chicken karage is a bit sweet which my tastebuds find strange. I expecting salty and savory. It just wasn't to my liking and expectations. The takoyaki are not round. It's like a very soft and warm ball that has been smashed on one side (because it sits on a plate). The texture is pretty soft from what I am used to (too mushy for me). The inside texture felt right and you don't have to digging for your octopus. 

The seafood pancake came relatively quickly after the rest of our appetizers came out. However, because we waited so long for it, we ended up just eating two pieces each and bringing the rest home. The pancake serving was large and slightly thick. I notice there was a lot of batter and not much condiments(?). 

I guess we may have ordered too much. I also wasn't expecting the appetizers to come out in separate dishes. If you want the samplers, do note that you only save $3. You can try and ask for them to come all at once so you can have a nice selection when you eat. 

Overall, this is not my kind of Korean (with Japanese touches) restaurant. However, this is not meant to be confused with I think the food is bad and not fresh because it seems to be. It's just that I didn't enjoy it all.
author: Jess W.

description:
The workers were okay, not that friendly. The waiter we had was attentive at least.

When we got there, it was pretty much empty. It was a good timing for us, since after we got our food, it started crowding with people.

So for the food, we got Kimchi Fried Rice and Budae jjigae (spicy sausage hot pot) ! For the Kimchi Fried Rice, the portions were pretty big which was nice. The vidual for both the restaurant and food were nice and pretty. We ordered those two things for three people and I think it was more than enough. 

Also, they have a big television. It played mostly kpop songs, ballads, and korean drama songs mostly while we were there. 

Would go again. :)
author: Olivia C.

description: Came here on a Thursday night around 7pm with a friend. Many empty tables but the food and service was great. My friend has a fish allergy and we let the server know ahead of time. When the server brought the side dishes she let us know which ones may contain fish. We used the check in for the free gyoza and those were really good. The server checked back on us several times and refilled the side dishes that ran low.
author: Ashley W.

description: It's not the best Korean food you'll get in the city (the wings at Tonight and Toyose are definitely better), and prices are a little high for portion sizes, but the food here is also made with more attention to detail. Also, while there's generally only one waiter for all 8-10 tables, you're going to get great service. Be prepared to wait for a seat if you want to eat here because it's tiny; otherwise, you can order to go, and it won't take long at all. Banchan is pretty limited, and portion sizes are on the smaller size, but when you notice how their kimchi fried rice or wings aren't gloopy like The Spot's, you start to appreciate this place a little more. It's not LA, but you could do far worse in the City. Their TVs also don't show Giants games, even against the bums. What's the deal?
author: Danny C.

description: Thinly sliced beef, ramen, gyoza are hard to screw up, so we definitely enjoyed our meal, but the quality of meat and the ramen was below what you'll find at many other places in the city. The ramen seemed like they came out of a nissin 25 cent packet (which again is not bad). The ribeye bulgogi didn't have much flavor so we just threw it in the ramen broth. Don't really believe it was ribeye either. They seemed understaffed by one waitress. Took forever to ask for more water or a spoon.
author: jones z.

description: We came here for the first time for a late night snack and ordered the seafood pancake, spicy pork, and sweet and garlic chicken wings.  The seafood pancake is huge and was crispy with lots of seafood inside.  We were surprised to see big shrimp!  The chicken wings were tasty but a bit on the pricey side for the amount you get.  Otherwise, they were satisfying.  The spicy pork was good and tasty as well.  Glad they were open late to accommodate us!
author: A. C.

description: Great food and quick service for a last minute dinner. I got the dolsot bibimbap and my fiancee got the spicy seafood tofu soup. We inhaled our food and went on our merry way within 30 minutes.
author: Daniel G.

description:
***Take out

Fast and easy! Kim Chee Fried Rice- amazing and huge portion. Spicy Pork- savory and just the right amount of heat!
author: Louis S.

description:
The food is fairly delicious. About 3.5 stars for me. Had the beef bulgolgi, seafood pancake, kim chee fried rice,  korean fried chicken, gyozas, and banchan. 
Have been to quite a few very popular Korean  places. In LA. This one is not bad comparatively. The banchan is skimpy compared to Korean restaurants in K Town Los Angeles.
author: Keo N.

description: I always crave for their kimchi fried rice. It is the best kimchi fried rice in the city! My boyfriend enjoys getting the kalbi and bulgogi which are both very juicy and tender. I also love how they always have different yelp check in specials! The service can vary, depending on how busy they are. They can get pretty crowded late at night. The prices are a little steep but I always have to return for the kimchi fried rice!
author: Christine K.

description:
This place is fairly good. Honestly, it was my toyose replacement because Saturday's at ten p.m. is a very busy time for Toyose and this was the closest Korean place open. It wasn't bad because it definitely hit the spot but I don't believe that everything was great or to-die-for. 

Our table ordered many things: chicken wings, seafood pancake, short ribs, rice cakes and free potstickers. The chicken wings were pretty yummy. They were covered in a garlic sauce that was the consistency of honey. Probably due to the look of the sauce, I expected it to be sweet. It wasn't sweet, it had a traditional Korean garlic chicken wing flavor. One note about the wing was that it was butchered differently than i expected. They left the wing tips on, but took half of the wing tip off. This obviously isn't anything negative or positive, I just thought it was funny looking. 
The seafood pancake was pretty good. It was really thick and doughy. I know that some people would like their pancakes to be thinner and crispier, but I really didn't mind the doughiness. 
The short ribs were good. The presentation was funny because the plate is in the shape of a cow LOL I thought that was hilarious. The grill marks on the meat were nice and gave it a good flavor. Short ribs are always pretty chewy, but I love eating it anyway. 
The rice cakes or dukbokki were pretty good. I think that the dish was a lot of sauce and not enough sustenance. At least the texture was good and the flavor was there. 
The pot stickers were good and a nice plus for Yelp users :D 

All in all, it was good, the kind of good you say after a boring first date. There really isn't anything bad to say about it, but there's no spark. I don't see myself choosing this place as a number one choice but I wouldn't mind coming here again if someone else suggests it.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night with the boyfriend. Service was on point, attentive, and informative!

-Japchae: the best you'll ever have. Soooo flavorful!

-Spicy Pork: mediocre. Wasn't that spicy. Meat to onion ratio was totally off. I didn't order spicy onions. 

-Spicy whole crispy chicken: (not sure if that's what it's called. It's the one that's $13.95 tho.) But this dish... I wanted to like it so bad but the purchase wasn't worth it! It was flavorful (but not spicy,) .. The square pieces of chicken had so much bone in it that it wasn't enjoyable to eat bc I had to keep spitting out bones. (Boyfriend said he just ate it bc he was lazy to spit it out, lol.) The wings/drums it comes with are so tiny and barely has any meat. Sucks bc the flavor was so yummy. 

-Gyoza: got this for free for checking in. It was ok. 

I'd probably only come back for the Japchae!
author: Ingrid E.

description:
I love the music ! 
And the food Spicy Pork is really yummmmm
Dont miss "rice wine" !
author: Noah P.

description: They got some pretty legit Korean food. Kimchee was one of the best I've had. I like how their wings are  crispy, not over fried, and not covered with excessive sauce. Seafood pancake was crispy and not too doughy, also a lot of shrimp  Galbi tang was on the salty side, beef was very tender though. Kimchee fried rice was very yummy, just wished they'd add some spam/bulgogi in it. Pot sticker was free for first Yelp check in, but I didn't have any just because I don't like my potstickers deep fried. My mom tried it and she liked it. Overall experience was good and food was yummy. I'll go back.
author: Jer D.

description:
I only recently discovered the wonderous dish that people call bibimbap so I was excited when my mom told me that a new korean restaurant opened a few blocks away from our house! This has been on my yelp bookmarks for a couple weeks now and I finally got to try it a few days ago for lunch with a friend.

Since we came for lunch, there were lunch specials that were very decently priced. Bibimbap for only $8.95?? Usually i'm at least paying $10-13 haha. Even though that's only a few dollars less, but hey, i'm a broke college student lol. I was a little sad I didn't see dolsot bibimbap on the lunch menu (the one with the stone pot that makes your rice all crunchy and yummmm), but I settled for the lunch special one because i'm cheap like that. My friend and I also checked in on yelp, which earned us a free plate of gyoza! You could tell they were fresh because we could barely eat them since they were too hot when the waiter brought it to us. The outside was perfectly crispy, btu I wish they gave more sauce! Also the banchan here is not too bad! Mine and my friend's favorite was the fishcake, which was a little spicy but not too much. It was also warm which I didn't expect haha. The cucumbers, yellow daikon, and broccoli were among my favorites as well.

The bibimbap came fairly quickly and it included a sunny side up egg, bulgolgi, spinach, lettuce (never seen lettuce in bibimbap before--but it worked), bean sprouts, seawed, carrots, and cucumbers, all over a bed of rice. The waiter also brought over the red sauce that's spicy/sweet and I basically drowned my rice in that haha, it's so good. My friend and I both ordered the bibimbap and it was more than enough for both of us; we were stuffed afterwards! 

Other than the food, the service was really good, there was only one waiter, but then again it was lunch time and not that crowded, so he was quite attentive on asking how our food was and making sure we had enough water.

I would definitely come back to try more things!
author: Tara A.

description:
Really good food. But really. Slow. Service. 

There were 8 of us so we were able to order a bunch of things. My favorite was sweet and spicy fried chicken. Finger lickin' good!  And the seafood pancake. They got it nice and crispy on the outside. 

Other highlights were the rice cake with fish cakes. This was the spiciest of all the dishes we got. A really nice kick. 

Bulgogi was also also tasty. I would like to try the kalbi next time. 

Kimchee fried rice wasn't memorable.  The spicy tofu stew lacked flavor. 

But overall, it was a good meal. 

The service was horrible though. The waitresses were SLOW. It was like we weren't there half the time.  At first, we only got one menu (hello, there are 8 of us!?) so we had to ask for more. Then we were ready to order and waited. And waited. And waited. Seriously. They kept walking back and forth, back and forth, totally ignoring us. We finally had to ask if we could order.  The food came out quickly enough but when we asked for rice bowls, the waitress balked at how many we wanted (uh, 8 for 8 people!?). Service is definitely a bit clueless.
author: Ada C.

description:
Looking at the reviews, I thought maybe I'll give this place a try. The environment was ghetto, cushions were dirty, seats were broken, my table was wobbling. I thought fine, let's not judge until I try their food.

It took them 30 minutes to bring my free check in gyoza, which tasted like the prepackaged Chinese potstickers you get from the supermarket. 10 minutes later my kimchee fried rice came, portion was big it was okay not very spicy. The overrated sweet and spicy chicken wings was a must on my list. After trying it, I was disappointed it was definitely not flavorful. It was mildly sweet and not spicy at all. It didn't taste fresh and it was $10.95 for 8 pieces. 

The reason why I gave them 2 stars because the service was good, poor waitress was running back and forth taking orders, cleaning tables, refilling water, setting tables. They need to hire another person because that's way too much work for one person on a busy night!
author: Angela L.

description:
First off, service was efficient and attentive. 

However, food was just mediocre. Seafood pancake was served as 6 huge slices which made it hard to dip in sauce. In retrospect, we could have further divided them into more manageable sizes, but it did not cross our minds until much later. It was the first time I have had a seafood pancake with unshelled pieces of shrimp, making it harder to enjoy in between spitting out shell pieces. The BBQ meats were pretty dry and bland so the dipping sauce was a welcome necessity.

We may come back to give the other items a chance, but not any time soon.
author: robin b.

description:
It's much harder to find good Korean food in San Francisco than one would expect. Especially in the Sunset where Vietnamese and Chinese restaurants dominate.

The Crew was a pleasant surprise. My sister and I were craving some good soondubu so we decided to give this place a shot. Honestly, it was a decent rendition, plus if you check in on Yelp, they give you free gyoza! Yum.

Delicious pickled vegetables galore plus some of the friendliest service we've ever received at any Asian establishment earns this place an extra star.

Will def have to come back here for the Korean fried chicken. Photos look fab.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Their food was really flavorful. I LOVED the tteokbokki and I added cheese and ramen noodles.
author: Tiffany R.

description: Every time I come here for dinner the waiters are always so friendly and nice! We asked for some substitutions to our meals and they had no problem with that and even said that was a great idea. Friendly environment and even when they were packed they didn't try to rush us out. Always love coming here.
author: James K.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend to have dinner. The waiter and waitress were very friendly and sat us down immediately. They were always aware when we finished our dishes and when our water was low. Their service was great.

We ordered the kimchi fried rice, bibimbap and chicken wings. I enjoyed the kimchi fried rice. The chicken wings were okay in my opinion.

I wouldn't mind coming here again.
author: Priscilla D.

description:
I came here yesterday for lunch and overall my experience was good for what it was. They have weird hours in that they close around 2pm and reopen around 5-5:30pm? So make sure you plan ahead otherwise you'll get stuck in their between closed hours. My friend and I were craving Korean food and since we were in the area, we decided to stop by and check out this place. We ordered the japchae (8.95) and garlic deep-fried chicken wings (10.95). Both of the dishes were pretty good; I was surprised at how the japchae had really good flavor and at how moist it was. The garlic wings were interesting in that it wasn't what I was expecting because I thought the sauce was going to be more sweet instead of salty, but it was still pretty good. We also got free gyoza by checking into the restaurant using the Yelp app! You can have hot tea here instead of cold water with no extra charge. Perfect for being in the cloudy Sunset! 

3 stars for food, 1 star for service because the waiter kept checking up on us, refilled our teas constantly, and brought out our food very quickly. I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here since I feel like I have other favorite korean restaurants in the city but if you live nearby or happen to be in the area this isn't a bad choice.
author: Kathleen S.

description: When it's cold outside and I don't feel like cooking but want something warm (besides pho), I come here for the galbi tang! Have it with a bowl of rice and that it just mm mmm good! The black pork belly, tofu soup and BBQ short rib are all also really good.
author: Eugenia G.

description:
My bf and I like this spot a lot. It's not the best Korean food I've ever tasted but it is at least above average. The odd thing is their fried chicken and spicy fried chicken isn't just wings, its sort of like an entire half chicken cut up and fried? I wasn't expecting that but it was still delicious. My go-to order here is the seafood soft tofu soup. Always delicious and a personal favorite.

The servers here are very hard working and although the times we've been here they seemed understaffed, we have never had issued with having to wait too long.
author: Melody S.

description: The Crew is decent for reliable korean food at average prices. Portions are big and great for eating family style. The gyoza with free checkin was  a nice touch! However, my friend paid and on our way out, the server literally stopped her with a pen asking for a bigger tip. We were a two person party that had few requests. The pressure of being put on the spot like that, when your financial situation is not obvious, definitely rubs me the wrong way and is hard to forget.
author: Bertha T.

description:
This place rocks!!!!  We started off with the Fried Chicken wing which were succulent, juicy, tossed with a sweet and spicy sauce and served hot and crunchy.  Just the perfect way to get going.

Our table orded the Jap Chae, Beef Shortribs, Shortrib Soup and Soon Tofu which was just about the pefect combination of spicy and savory for the entire table.  Bahn Chan was plentiful and replaced frequently.  Everything was cooked very well and the star really was the soup with tender falling off the bone meat in a slighly sweet elixer broth.  Soon tofu was properly served with a raw egg to drop into the piping hot bowl.

Now the kicker....service is some of the best I've EVER received in a Korean restaurant.  Can't wait to get back and try the rest of the menu.
author: Dude D.

description:
Love the Lunch specials here.  And excellent service as usual.  

And no wait-- food came fast.  Delicious and gluten free too (bibimbap without the paste sauce)
author: George K.

description:
I came here for a late dinner, and this place is charming! I like the set-up, and I especially like how private most of the tables are.

I tried the kimchi fried rice, deep fried garlic chicken wings, and spicy tofu soup. The fried rice was really good, and it was a pretty big portion. If you love garlic, you must try their chicken wings. There was just a tad too much garlic for my taste. And the tofu soup was delicious! It really hit the spot on a cold, rainy night. The spice level was perfect, and it was nice and hearty. The banchan was a little disappointing - not much variety. 

The workers are very friendly, but they took a long time giving the bill and taking the payment form.
author: Rachel H.

description: This place is alright. Not the best place to go to if you want a good korean food dinner. Everything was extremely salty for some reason. The food was not bad but just too salty that I need to make sure I eat a lot of rice to cover the salt. Meats were not over cook. The server was nice and attentive.
author: Sury C.

description:
Nice place, with a chill atmosphere.. Servers were friendly and our food came prettu quick! We ordered the kalbi short ribs, kimchi fried rice, and jap chae!
The winners for me was the kalbi short ribs and jap chae, the kimchi fried rice wasnt the best.. 
But OMG.. Their kalbi short ribs are the best ones I've ever had! MUST TRY.
author: Alyssa C.

description: I gave the crew 5 stars because I am not a hater. Food was great. Service was better than what I read on some of the reviews. I would definitely recommend the crew to anyone who wants good Korean food, and is not a douche. I will be coming back:)
author: Justin B.

description: Came here with my mates with huge appetites. This place did not disappoint. Gyoza medium spice was fantastic although not very spicy at all. Next time will have to try the mango habanero version. Fried oyster was consumed even faster. So we all ordered the half and half. Short ribs were fall off the bone with tender bbq flavor. The beef ribeye bulgogi was stacked high, so much food! We did our best to finish our plates. Will be back
author: Ali N.

description: DO NOT order the bibimbap..... What authentic Korean bibimbap has mixed greens, choys, and enoki mushrooms.
author: Emily Y.

description: Very good food and service! There is a variety of different selections of Korean food and the portions are very generous. I ordered one of the selections in the soups, pots, and stews section. It was the kimchi and ramen (#49). It was very good. The spiciness definitely climbs as you eat more and more. The soup was amazing. Definitely will be coming back!
author: Kelly O.

description:
This place was decent, but I'd rather go to another place like Manna where food is cheaper and tastier. Although it was pretty empty at 7:30pm and is really easy to miss so you probably wouldn't ever have to wait. One cool thing about this place is that it's open until 2am! Also, it's a Korean/Japanese fusion restaurant supposedly, but I didn't really notice any Japanese fusion dishes on the menu. 

Our nice waitress started us off with banchan after she took our order. The dishes were not as fresh as what I've tried at other places. To make up for this, you can check in on yelp to get a free order of gyoza, which is pretty good! Perfectly crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. Awesome check-in offer.

For my main dish, I decided to play it safe and order the Dolsot Bibimbap ($12.95). But it was a little disappointing because although it came with lots of veggies, the meat portion was very small. My bf ordered their Bulgolgi ($16.95). Not the best, but it was tasty. Don't know if it's worth the price though. 

Decent food, but a little pricey for what it is. I may come back only because it's so close to my bf's house. I'll probably try the sweet and spicy chicken next time if I do - it looked really good!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
The Crew is hip little Korean restaurant in the Outer Sunset/Noreiga area. This place is chill and the food is up to par with some of my favorite Korean restaurants in San Diego. I'm so glad they opened up here in Sunset, SF :)

SETTING
-Nice, clean, bright small medium sized restaurant, ~8 or so tables, never totally crowded so you can get a seat right away (win!).
-Service is awesome. The waiter was super nice at refilling our water and banchan without us asking. He also packed our leftovers to-go for us.
-Open late at night! They close at 2am!

FOOD
-Fried Gyoza! Free if you check-in on Yelp! Straight out of the fryer. Crispy. Delicious. Best of all, free! 
-Dolsot Bibimbap. Super hot, straight from the oven! TIP: When they serve it, let it sit for a few minutes, so the rice will cook into a nice crunchy texture. They served it with fresh ENOKI mushrooms, lettuce strips, carrot, beef bulgolgi, sea weed, and spinach. I've never seen dolsot bibimbap with enoki before, bonus points :) for them. Really delicious and great for SF weather.
-Sweet and Spicy Korean Fried Chicken. They ran out of this the first time I tried this place, so I was really excited to get it this time around!! The plate is HUGE. Chicken Wings galore. The sauce wasn't that spicy and had the right amount of flavor - nothing too heavy, nothing too salty or sweet. PERFECT for eating in large quantities without getting a stomach ache :) :) Get this! 
-Banchan. Korean side dishes - all really good and fresh! Yellow daikon radish, fish cake, bean sprouts, broccoli, kimchi, and a spicy bean sprouts dish. 

PROS
-Opens late at night :)
-Always can get a table right away
-Free gyoza when you check-in
-TASTY KOREAN FOOD :9
author: Grace J.

description:
Came here the other day with my husband and kids. It was close to the house so we figured let's give the place a try.

First of all, the service was friendly and they accommodated the kids really well. It's hard to find a kid friendly environment. 

Second, the food came out pretty quick. We ordered the sweet & spicy fried chicken, kimchee pancake, and the curry pork belly. Everything was tasty and it definitely hit the craving. 

Overall, nice place for a quick dinner in the neighborhood with friendly staff.

Will be back again.
author: Diana P.

description:
Spicy Pork done perfectly. 
Grilled Chicken not overdone. 
Nice complement of sides. You can ask for more. 

First time I tried Hite Beer. Very light and refreshing!
author: brian k.

description: The Crew is my go to place for Korean food, especially when I'm feeling under the weather. Their tofu soup is pretty good as well as their side dishes. I've never had a terrible experience with customer service so I must be coming on the best days. Even today, it was a full house for lunch and there was only one waitress working. She still managed to keep the place under control which was pretty awesome.
author: Korra B.

description: The short-rib soup is a must order!  Comes in a deeper bowl with very tender, fall-off-the-bone short ribs,  radishes,  glass noodles, green onions, egg whites, and in a flavorful broth.  The garlic fries chicken wings, imo, were also tasty & crispy.  I recommend & will make a return trip to The Crew.
author: Jessica S.

description: The food and service were generally good but I found two black hairs in my bibimbap (my hair is light brown). I thought it was a bit too pricy in comparison to other similar restaurants in the area, but I would go here again if I were hungry and nearby.
author: N G.

description:
Upon entering, it was not crazy busy which is weird because it was around 7:30pm. The place is still probably somewhat new... The waitress was nice. She gave us hot tea pretty quickly.

We ordered:

-Yogurt Soju: We were about to get the lychee one, but the waitress didn't recommend it unless you really like the strong alcohol taste. The yogurt one was pretty good.

- Kimchi Fried Rice: Wasn't too spicy. Wished there was a little more egg though. It's nothing special.

- Seafood pancake: They used imitation crab = no no. It just downgraded the quality. My stomach couldn't handle it.

- Deep Fried Chicken Wings: This was mentioned quite a lot on Yelp, so we ordered it. The chicken came out to be moist, which was good. But there was no "WOW" factor. It's a typical fried chicken dish that you can get anywhere.

- Croquette: It's good. It came with what it seems to be a Thousand Island dipping sauce. I'd rather eat it without the sauce and I did just that.

- Gyoza: Free if you check in on Yelp. Nothing "WOW", but I like free...

Would I come back? Probably not, since it's quite far from where I live.
author: Jane C.

description: Ordered the chicken sundubu and whole fried chicken (sweet and spicy) for takeout. Even though we got the sundubu with no spice, it was still very tasty. They even included a little box of banchan. The chicken ended up being a little soggy by the time we got home but not much you can do about that. The place is exactly what you'd expect from late night korean food.
author: Clinton L.

description: Went here on a Friday night around 8pm with a buddy. We were seated within 10minutes. We ordered some beef bulgogi, Kim-Chee fried rice and the garlic chicken wings. Everything tasted great and was served hot. The waitress was awesome as she was very willing to explain how they serve and how food is portioned out. Was an awesome experience. I wish they made kimchee fried rice burritos!
author: J B.

description:
A great place to grab Korean food for lunch!   

Food is always fresh and service is very friendly and prompt for a small restaurant.  
There is usually one server during lunch who hustles to keep all the diners happy!
author: Lucky L.

description:
The Good:
unlimited banchan
kimchi fried rice
kimchi pancake (without the hair)
service
kalbi was good although I had only a small piece

The Bad:
mango soju tasted artificial and way too sweet
kimchi pancake had a hair cooked into it and good thing we found out while we were digging into the last and not the first piece
plain fried chicken was too salty although everyone liked it better than the same fried chicken with the sweet and spicy sauce for an additional $2

I would come again although the hair grossed me out.  It's a small restaurant so it got full just after 6pm on a Friday.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Normally, I would have given this place 3.5 stars but rounded up instead of down for two reasons.

1. Free Gyoza if you check in on yelp
2. Quality of food plus variety of banchan(mini side dishes)

I came here with a friend to try out this new Korean bar food establishment. I use to come here when it was called Pine and served regular Korean BBQ food.

We ordered the usual suspects which were kimchee fried rice, spicy rice cakes with ramen, and seafood pancake. We also received our free Gyoza and about 6 side dishes.

Overall, I would say the food quality is better than other Korean drinking spots in the city but it is also pricier than other places so you are paying for the quality.

Side note: They were blasting a Pandora Boyz 2 Men radio station and all the old school r&b jams which led us to go Karoake after dinner.

Food Highlight: Free Gyoza and assortment of banchan.
author: Rich L.

description:
This is a pretty decent Japanese/Korean fusion restaurant. I came here last night with a few other people and a couple dishes made me cry happy tears, no lie (: I want to give this place a 3.5 but that's not an option so i'll just put 3 because it's not quite at 4 yet lol 

-Takoyaki ($5.95): came with 6 pieces. This was REALLY good while it was hot lol. The outside was a little bit crunchy and the octopus on the inside was tender and not super chewy.

-BBQ Short Rib, Kalbi ($22.95): gave us a decent amount of ribs. It was not overcooked, which I really liked. It was really tender and perfectly marinated but honestly since it was cooked on the medium side, it was somewhat hard to eat. Still good though.

-Al Jjigae, Roe Stew ($12.95): this is a spicy korean soup with fish egg inside. This was not that good. The fish egg was extremely rough and WAAAY overcooked. The soup was too salty also and for the price, we didn't get that much. I definitely wouldn't get this again if I eat here again.

-Deep Fried Chicken Wings ($8.95): came with 8 pieces. THESE WANGS THO. This is a MUST GET item here. I don't know what else to say. They were some REALLY good wings. Crunchy on the outside, juicy on the inside.
